div.p: Edible insects have been proposed as a sustainable future protein source for a growing global population. Overseas, interest has seen investment in start-up companies specialising in producing insects for human consumption. Yet little is known of the edible insect species in Aotearoa New Zealand or whether New Zealanders are willing to consume insects. To address this, I investigated the current landscape of edible insects in Aotearoa. I created a catalogue of species with traditional and contemporary uses, the companies that are producing insect-based products and the social and legislative landscape they exist in. I then explored the social licence for insects as food, using a questionnaire to examine the perceptions and experiences of 620 participants, finding an openness to insects as food, influenced by prior experience, knowledge, and a low food neophobia score. However, this was tempered by sentiment analysis showing insect ingredients were viewed more negatively than other food ingredients suggesting an unconscious bias. The huhu beetle, Prionoplus reticularis, was widely listed by participants as an edible insect in Aotearoa, suggesting a potential candidate for future farming. However, surprisingly little is known about the biology of this well-known beetle. To address this, I used GCMS to explore the metabolomic profile of this species along a latitudinal gradient. I found that a random forest model trained on this data was able to predict the geographic location of a larvae with reasonable accuracy, providing a possible tool to detect the provenance of edible insects in the future. I investigated the beetles' scramble competition mating system, and, using static allometry and flight mills, I found evidence of the interplay of sexual selection and stabilising selection on traits associated with male fitness in this species. I also found evidence of sexual dimorphism in the species, indicating the importance of female chemical cues to male mate searching. Using scanning electron microscopy, I investigated the antennal ultrastructure of male and female P. reticularis, describing unique, sexually dimorphic sensilla in this species. This thesis serves as a starting point for the development of edible insects in Aotearoa.
Firstly, I have to thank my wonderful supervisors, Greg Holwell, Leilani Walker and Thomas Buckley. Greg, you are a wonderful human being who exemplifies kindness, caring and empathy.

I really appreciate the support you have provided, whether it be through global pandemics or concussions, you make things work and I could not have done this thesis without you. The meetings, field trips and frequent discussion of '80s and '90s action movies have been a joy.

Leilani, you are one of the smartest people I know, and I really appreciated how you have challenged my thinking and I think that is reflected in my thesis. You switched between friend and supervisor hats with aplomb, and our trip to the Bishop Museum and karaoke in Hawaii was one of the highlights of my thesis. Thomas, I'm sorry I didn't get to work more with you, but I did enjoy our chats at Manaaki Whenua. I regret running out of time to explore the genomics of the huhu beetle, the pandemic has a few things to answer for and this was one of them.

Chapter 1 A General Introduction to Insects as Food "If we could get over our phobia of eating insects you could solve world starvation. It's high protein, no fat, extreme nutrients, and they're just abundant, they're everywhere. But, no, we're not going to do that!"

There likely comes a point in every doctoral candidate's journey, where critically acclaimed, Academy Award winning actor, Nicolas Cage, summarises four years of their work in an offhand comment to Entertainment Weekly (Collis, 2023). Whilst insects do contain fat, Mr. Cage correctly points out the potential of edible insects to address concerns of protein supply as humanity's global population increases, but also acknowledges the perceived disgust and reticence of many cultures, but particularly in the west, to consume insects. However, it is not just Hollywood stars suggesting insects could be a solution to our food security concerns.
With the global population expected to reach 9 billion by 2050, the Food and Agriculture

Organisation of the United Nations (FAO) estimates that the global agricultural demand will increase by 50 percent of the demand in 2013 (Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, 2017). In light of this challenge, there has been increased interest in the place of insects within the human diet. Entomophagy is already a common practice in many cultures, with over 1,500 recorded species of insects consumed globally (Van Itterbeeck & Pelozuelo, 2022) by several hundred-million people (van Huis et al., 2022). Globally, few insect species are reared commercially at an industrial scale for food, with the majority being wild harvested. The primary species reared commercially for human consumption are crickets (e.g. Acheta domestica, Gryllus bimaculatus, Teleogryllus commodus) and mealworms (e.g. Alphitobius diaperinus, Tenebrio molitor, Zophobas morio) (van Huis, 2016). However, interest in eating insects has only increased in western cultures over the past decade.
The production of insects can be achieved through wild-harvest, semi-domestication, or farming.

Wild harvesting has been practiced by humans for millennia and is particularly effective for gregarious species of insects allowing for efficient collection. The wild harvesting of insects can be practiced as a form of biocontrol for pest species in agriculture whilst supplementing protein in the diet. A successful example can be seen with Patanga succincta locusts which were a major agricultural pest in Thailand prior to a successful campaign to use them as food (Hanboonsong, 2010). Semi-domestication involves manipulating the environment to facilitate the rearing of insects for part of their lifecycle. For example, palm trees in some South-East Asian countries will be cut down to provide palm weevil breeding sites (Yen, 2015). Farming incorporates the entire lifecycle of the insect in an environmentally controlled environment with varying degrees of automation. Possibly the oldest example of farming insects is silk farming, which has been practiced for over 5000 years. Silk production was the primary objective here with the decocooned pupae a by-product that was used as food (Cherry, 1987).

The lower environmental impacts of rearing insects for food are often cited to increase the sustainability of our food production systems, compared to conventional sources of animal protein production (Halloran et al., 2017;Oonincx et al., 2010;Oonincx & de Boer, 2012). Life cycle assessments, an analytical tool to assess the environmental impact of a product, suggest that land-use and greenhouse gas emissions of insect-rearing are lower than other forms of livestock (Bosch et al., 2019;Halloran et al., 2017;Nikkhah et al., 2021;Oonincx & de Boer, 2012), however, this is dependent on the rearing methods used (Bosch et al., 2019;Oonincx & de Boer, 2012). In comparison to traditional livestock, insects, which are poikilotherms, have a favourable food conversion ratio (FCR) with some species able to utilise low quality or non-traditional feedstocks that may otherwise be seen as a waste stream (e.g., some cerambycid larvae can consume forestry waste, mealworms can utilise vegetable scraps and brewer's yeast). The FCR (kg feed/kg of fresh weight) for mealworms is 2.2 which compares to 2.3 in poultry, 4.0 in swine, and 2.7 -8.8 in beef (depending on the feed used) (Oonincx & de Boer, 2012).

Like other livestock, the rearing of insects also produces greenhouse gasses (GHGs) and waste comprised of exuviae (moulted insect skin) and frass (faeces and undigested substrate) which also produces GHGs. Insects, and their frass, produce much lower carbon dioxide (CO 2 ), methane (CH 4 ) and nitrous oxide (N 2 O) than cattle making them a more environmentally sustainable solution than conventional livestock (Oonincx et al., 2010). The production of ammonia (NH 3 ), which causes nitrification of waterways and indirectly N 2 O production, is also lower and, combined with the ability to utilise waste streams from other areas of primary production, the frass can be used in the agricultural system as a fertiliser enabling a circular economy (Dicke, 2018;Oonincx & de Boer, 2012).

The land use to produce one kilogram of insect protein is considerably smaller than other forms of livestock (de Vries & de Boer, 2010; Oonincx & de Boer, 2012) with production of one kilogram of mealworm protein requiring 43% and 10% of the land required to produce one kilogram of animal protein of dairy and beef respectively. This is due to the small size of the insect allowing for vertical farming, efficient conversion of feed, and their feed being derived from by-products rather than pasture (Oonincx & de Boer, 2012). Similarly to land use, water use is also much lower for insect production with beef requiring five times the amount of water to produce the equivalent unit of mealworm protein (112 L/g to 23 L/g respectively) (Miglietta et al., 2015). Again, the high feed efficiency of mealworms is attributed to this small water footprint.

However, there are challenges associated with the use and development of insect-based food production. Yen (2008) highlights the important role of conservation and traditional ecological knowledge in avoiding over exploitation should wild harvesting of insects increase in Australia.

There have been instances where the popularity of an insect, and loss of traditional ecological knowledge, has resulted in over-harvesting in the wild leading to localised extinction (Ramos-Elorduy, 2006). Wild harvesting can also be compounded by land use change, intensive agriculture and climate change (Yen, 2008) as shown in the case of the Australian edible insect, the bogong moth (Agrotis infusa) which migrates between lowland pastures and alpine regions (where it is harvested by First Nations people). Arsenic from agricultural sprays used in the low land areas is accumulated by the moth and transported to fragile alpine ecosystems (Green, 2008;Green et al., 2001) elevating the presence of arsenic in these areas.

Farming insects also carries challenges and risks. Whilst being a poikilotherm benefits feed conversion efficiency, the same trait requires that the farmer maintain an optimal rearing temperature for the insect. This can result in higher energy use than livestock such as dairy, poultry and pork which, depending on the energy source used, can increase GHG emissions (Oonincx & de Boer, 2012). There is ample opportunity to reduce this energy use through careful selection of the species (such as those adapted to the ambient environment), optimising the rearing environment (e.g., through insulation), and using renewable or waste energy (e.g., geothermal, waste heat from industrial processes). Other risks can come from chemical contaminants from the insect feed being bioaccumulated: heavy metals (Diener et al., 2015;Lindqvist & Block, 1995;Purschke et al., 2017;van der Fels-Klerx et al., 2016), residues of dioxins, polychlorinated biphenyls and polyaromatic hydrocarbons (Charlton et al., 2015) and pesticides can also be present (Purschke et al., 2017). Insects can also be mechanical vectors of biological contaminants such as bacteria (Klunder et al., 2012;Stoops et al., 2016), parasites and prions (Müller et al., 2019;Post et al., 1999). These risks, by no means unique to insects, highlight the importance of quality assurance throughout the supply chain, from selection of feeds and substrates when rearing insects through to post-harvest treatment and storage (van der Fels-Klerx et al., 2018) and existing risk-mitigations can be adapted from the food industry.

There are numerous start-ups around the globe specialising in rearing edible insects, and 500,000 tonnes of insect protein per annum is predicted to be produced by 2030 (de Jong & Nikolik, 2021). However, it is difficult to approximate the size of the current edible insect market as many early-stage companies are reticent to share details of their production capacity. An example of the scale of commercial production can be seen in Thailand where around 20,000 cricket farms supply 7,500 tonnes per annum and are the primary source of income for many farmers (Hanboonsong et al., 2013). Several companies in Thailand also export to overseas markets, including New Zealand.

A growing interest in eating insects in the west is contrasted against a perceived historic dislike of insects as food in most Western cultures. Several studies have investigated Western consumers' perceptions of insects and suggested various strategies to increase market uptake of insects as food (See reviews by: Alhujaili et al., 2023;Ardoin & Prinyawiwatkul, 2021). There are, however, isolated examples of insects having been consumed in a traditional setting in Western countries.
For example, cockchafer beetles in France and Germany were made into a soup; it was proposed that rocky mountain locusts be eaten to control their numbers in the United States of America;

and a traditional delicacy, casu marzu, is a cheese consumed in regions including and surrounding Sardinia that contain the larvae of the dipteran, Piophila casei (Lockwood, 2004;van Huis, 2013van Huis, , 2020;;van Huis & Tomberlin, 2016).

Cerambycids are used as a food source in many cultures around the world (Chakravorty et al., 2011;Gahukar, 2011;Mitsuhashi, 2003;Pond, 1994;Schrader et al., 2016;Turpin & Si, 2017) with the larvae and, in some cases, the adult life stage being consumed. In all cases cerambycids are derived from wild harvest when seasonally available. This poses a constraint on consumption which limits uptake and risks exploitation of wild populations. Aotearoa is host to a well-known edible prionine cerambycid, the huhu beetle Prionoplus reticularis White 1843 (Coleoptera:
Cerambycidae).

P. reticularis is saproxylic, feeding on a range of native and exotic timber and can reach high densities in stands of Pinus radiata (Edwards, 1956(Edwards, , 1959(Edwards, , 1961c)). Much of what is known about the biology of P. reticularis is shaped by its role as a pest of untreated timber and efforts to stop it (Cross, 1994;Dentener et al., 1999Dentener et al., , 2001;;Hedley et al., 1979;Hood & Gardner, 2004;G. Hosking, 2007;Lester et al., 2000;Murray, 1973;Pawson et al., 2020;Pawson & Sky, 2009;Pawson & Watt, 2009). The larvae are relatively slow growing, taking between two and three years feeding on decaying wood prior to making a pupal chamber and maturing into the nonfeeding adult stage (Rogers et al., 2002). Despite feeding on a fairly nutrient poor substrate, the adult beetle can accrue substantial energy reserves, a feat likely due to the diverse range of rare microbial phylotypes inhabiting its digestive system (Reid et al., 2011). Upon eclosion, the adult beetle spends roughly two weeks searching for mates and ovipositioning sites, whilst surviving on energy stores accrued as a larvae (Edwards, 1961c). These energy stores are reflected in the nutritional profile of P. reticularis, which contains relatively high levels of lipids (~58 % by dry weight in the pupae), with protein extracts being of good nutritional quality, and abundant in manganese, magnesium, phosphorus, iron, copper, and zinc (Hutchins & Christmas, 1973;Kavle et al., 2022bKavle et al., , 2022aKavle et al., , 2023)). Cadmium and lead is also detectable, however at moderate levels of consumption, P. reticularis are safe to eat (Kavle et al., 2022a). P. reticularis is a well-known and culturally significant species that historically has been regarded as a food item, eaten raw or roasted (Best, 1902;Miller, 1952). The larvae are known to vary in flavour depending on the wood they have been feeding on (Pond, 1994), indicating that the compounds in different timber influence the chemical profile of the larvae.

Whilst the huhu beetle is the most well-known edible insect, several insect species have been used as a traditional food source and a contemporary industry appears to be forming around a variety of native and exotic edible insect species. Despite this nascent industry, there is little scientific literature around which species of insects have been traditionally consumed and their basic biology and life histories. This knowledge gap underscores the need for comprehensive research to not only identify insect species but also understand their fundamental biological attributes and life cycles. Such insights are essential for the sustainable development and informed promotion of the edible insect industry in New Zealand.

div.head: Thesis Outline
div.p: This thesis is guided by an emphasis on the identified need for multi-and trans-disciplinary approaches to advance the edible insect industry (van Huis, 2017). In this thesis, I aim to understand the social licence of edible insects in this country by investigating (1) the diversity and history of use of edible insect species in Aotearoa New Zealand and their place within our culture, and ( 2) the uses and perceptions of New Zealanders towards consuming insects. I then focus on the biology of a well-known, but little researched, endemic edible insect species, the huhu grub P. reticularis to: (1) develop and assess the potential of metabolomic techniques to identify the provenance of edible insect species, using P. reticularis as a case study, (2) investigate the mating system of P. reticularis using static allometry and flight mills to assess the importance of traits associated with fitness in a scramble competition mating system, and (3) describe the sexually dimorphic antennal ultrastructure of P. reticularis to shed light on the importance of chemical ecology on this mating system.
In Chapter 2, I conduct a comprehensive review of the use of insects in Aotearoa New Zealand.

For this, I reviewed the literature, grey literature, newspaper articles, existing legislation, companies register, and websites of businesses selling insects for food, to (a) catalogue known species of insects used for food, past and present, (b) review what is currently known about potential native insect food species to identify promising candidates for rearing, (c) investigate the legislative and social landscape companies operate in, and (d) catalogue companies operating in this sector over the last 10 years, and how they market edible insects to the public.

In Chapter 3, using an online questionnaire, I explore the use and perceptions of the public towards insects as food in Aotearoa. The objective of this questionnaire was to identify the acceptability of insects as food, the traits associated with a willingness to eat insects, existing knowledge of edible insects, and the sentiments people exhibit towards insects as food. I analyse the data using a variety of techniques, including machine learning and sentiment analysis. I discuss my findings in the context of seemingly contradictory findings in Chapter 2.
After exploring the social licence within which the edible insect industry operates, I move to the biology of a charismatic edible insect species, that is well known to the public, the huhu beetle.

Chapter 4 assesses the potential of metabolomic fingerprinting as a tool for determining the provenance of an edible insect species. To achieve this, I sample the larvae of P. reticularis along a natural latitudinal gradient the length of Aotearoa. I compare two different derivatisation techniques using GC-MS to create a metabolomic profile of beetles from different locations. I then use a variety of statistical techniques to describe the variance in metabolic traits and train and test a random forest classification model to predict which location a larvae came from.

Chapter 5 focuses on unravelling the intricacies of P. reticularis' scramble competition mating system, characterised by intense male competition for access to females. The objective of this chapter is to discern the extent of sexual dimorphism and patterns of allometry on traits that are important for male fitness in scramble competition: sensory and locomotory traits. In this chapter, I design and build a flight mill to assess how wing size and body size influence flight performance. This chapter identifies tension between sexual selection and stabilising selection, contrasting P. reticularis with other species exhibiting scramble competition mating systems.

Chapter 6 builds on the findings of Chapter 5, by using scanning electron microscopy to describe in detail the sensory ultrastructures and dimorphism found in the antennae of P. reticularis. This chapter reveals unique structures only present on the male antennae and I discuss possible implications for the sensory ecology of this species.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: The world's rapidly growing population, expected to reach over 9.7 billion by 2050 (United Nations, 2019), along with an increase in the wealth of developing countries, will increase the demand for animal proteins for food (Boland et al., 2013) and raises concerns for food security (Godfray et al., 2010). Insects have been highlighted by the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) (van Huis et al., 2013) as an important source of dietary protein and, due to key aspects of their biology, some insect species are a more sustainable option than sources of protein from livestock, poultry or seafood. Insects are poikilothermic (Byrd & Castner, 2002) which means energy gained from food is allocated to growth rather than maintaining body temperature (Bartley et al., 1980). This allows for a feed conversion efficiency higher than poultry and much higher than mammalian livestock (Nakagaki & Defoliart, 1991;Rumpold & Schlüter, 2013). Generally, most insects produce lower levels of greenhouse gasses than mammals and some species have the potential to convert organic waste into valuable products. Internationally, around 92% of edible insect species are wild harvested with 6% being semi-domesticated (i.e. not isolated from wild input) and 2% of species are farmed (Yen, 2015).

Most current research attention is directed towards farming a small number of cosmopolitan species, however, the insect kingdom in incredibly diverse and I would be shortsighted not to investigate other insects that are used as food around the world. The Pacific is often overlooked in discussions of insects as food despite having several wild harvested cerambycid species that are consumed, including Agrianome fairmairei, Oletherius spp., and Prionoplus reticularis which are consumed in New Caledonia, Fiji, Futuna, Sāmoa, Tonga and New Zealand (Pond, 1994;Schintu & Fasquel, 2019). In New Zealand, there are several edible insect species that have been recorded in the literature: the aforementioned P. reticularis, Pyronota festiva (Coleoptera: Scarabaeidae), Aenetus virescens (Lepidoptera: Hepialidae) (Jongema, 2017;Meyer-Rochow & Changkija, 1997).

As a nation in which the majority of the population are of European descent (Stats NZ Tatauranga Aotearoa, 2018), consumption of insects in Aotearoa New Zealand is not perceived to be a common practice. Some insects, of which the huhu beetle larvae (P. reticularis) is best known, were consumed prior to European arrival. There is, however, an increasing interest in entomophagy in Aotearoa New Zealand (O'Connor et al., 2023;P. Payne et al., 2023). However, with a small number of exceptions, most insect food products in Aotearoa New Zealand are imported exotic species, characteristics which make it difficult to assess the sustainability and environmental impact of production.

Given this increasing interest in entomophagy amongst consumers, I believe that this is a worthwhile time to review the current state of entomophagy in Aotearoa New Zealand both within the market and current research into insect food production. I reviewed the literature, grey literature, newspaper articles, existing legislation, companies register, and websites of businesses selling insects for food, to (a) catalogue known species of insects used for food, past and present, and (b) review what is currently known about potential endemic food species to identify promising candidates for rearing, and (c) investigate the legislative and social landscape companies operate in, and (d) catalogue companies operating in this sector, and how they market edible insects to the public.

div.head: Definitions
div.p: Under the Food Standards Australia New Zealand Act 1991, "food" broadly refers to substances for human consumption, including ingredients, additives and substances used in preparation. It excludes goods with a therapeutic use i.e., medicines. Delineating between insects eaten entirely for nutrition rather than therapeutic good can be difficult especially when considering historical consumption (see Meyer-Rochow & Changkija, 1997) so I will include insects in this review that may have had dual purposes. For the purposes of this review, edible insects and entomophagy will only include the consumption of insects themselves and exclude products made by insects (e.g., honey). Definitions for te reo Māori are included in Table 1.
Table 1. Definitions for te reo Māori terms. These are derived from Te Aka Māori Dictionary however many of these terms have deeper philosophical nuances that cannot be adequately captured here.

Term Definition Iwi Extended kinship group, tribe, nation, people, nationality, race -often refers to a large group of people descended from a common ancestor and associated with a distinct territory Kaitiaki Trustee, minder, guard, custodian, guardian, caregiver, keeper, steward Kaupapa Māori Māori approach, Māori topic, Māori customary practice, Māori institution, Māori agenda, Māori principles, Māori ideology -a philosophical doctrine, incorporating the knowledge, skills, attitudes, and values of Māori society Kōrero Speech, narrative, story, news, account, discussion, conversation, discourse, statement, information. Mātauranga Māori Māori knowledge -the body of knowledge originating from Māori ancestors, including the Māori world view and perspectives, Māori creativity and cultural practices Rohe Boundary, district, region, territory, area, border (of land) Tangata whenua Local people, hosts, indigenous people -people born of the whenua, i.e., of the placenta and of the land where the people's ancestors have lived and where their placenta are buried. Taonga Treasure, anything prized -applied to anything considered to be of value including socially or culturally valuable objects, resources, phenomenon, ideas, and techniques Te ao Māori The Māori worldview Te reo Māori The Māori language Te Tiriti o Waitangi The treaty of Waitangi; the document signed in 1840 which guides the relationship between the Crown and Māori Waitangi Tribunal The Waitangi Tribunal is a standing commission of inquiry. It makes recommendations on claims brought by Māori relating to legislation, policies, actions, or omissions of the Crown that are alleged to breach the promises made in the Treaty of Waitangi Waka Canoe or vessel. Allied kinship groups descended from the crew of a canoe which migrated to New Zealand and occupying a set territory Whakapapa Genealogy, genealogical table, lineage, descent

div.head: Species catalogue
div.p: The species catalogue was composed of insects, endemic, native, and exotic, that are used in New Zealand for human consumption at present and historically. This was collated from the literature, grey literature, newspaper articles and businesses selling insects for food. Only a small number of endemic insect species appear in written records as being a food source and it is likely that knowledge relating to the harvesting and preparation of insects as food is held in oral histories or has been lost through colonisation. It should be stressed that the species presented that may have had a traditional use as food have not been confirmed with mana whenua and future research would greatly benefit from this (See O 'Connor et al., 2023).

The grey literature shows there was often confusion with names in Te Reo Māori, variation in terms between different iwi, misidentification of species and substantial taxonomic revision since original publication (Best, 1902;Ehau-Taumaunu et al., 2020;Miller, 1952). Settler accounts of insects being used as food should be viewed in the context of colonisation. The eating of insects has been used as evidence that a culture is "primitive" as opposed to "civilised" which has been used as a justification for colonisation as noted by Kosonen (2022), "so-called "primitive" foodways like entomophagy have been instrumentalized in the colonial differentiations between civilization and primitivism". Further, an ethnographer's interest may bias their interpretation of their observations (Mercier et al., 2022). For instance Drummond (1927a) states "as civilisation fosters fastidiousness, insects as food are repugnant to most civilised peoples". Yet, in Europe, the collection of the agricultural pest, Melontha sp., was practiced by French and Germans and the soup produced from it was considered a delicacy well into the 1900's (J. J. Schneider, 1844;van Huis, 2020). In a similar fashion, some caterpillars were noted as pests of Māori but also served as food, medicine and artistic ingredients (Mercier et al., 2022).

It would be naive to believe that the available literature accurately encompasses all pre-European uses of insects by Māori. While the anthropological record has identified species which were "traditionally" consumed, it is not possible to extrapolate how frequent and how widespread these practices were. An incalculable amount of knowledge of te ao Māori remains within oral histories and future studies would greatly benefit from a kaupapa Māori-led approach.

Consumption of most endemic/native species of insects has been largely replaced by exotic species imported from overseas (Table 3). Of the ten known insect species that may have been included in a pre-European diet, only the huhu beetle (P. reticularis) is the widely known and used, frequently appearing in food festivals, popular culture and, briefly, a vodka brand (Gordon, 2015;Modlik & Johnston, 2017;Schulz, 2019;Ward, 2013). The larvae of the huhu beetle are perhaps the most well-known of the insects in New Zealand that have been eaten as food. Wild harvest is currently the sole means of production of this insect for food and whilst there has been little research attention with the aim of commercial production of the species, there has been some research on their biology and ecology due to their potential as a pest in the timber products industry (e.g., Alma & van Boven, 1975;Cross, 1994;Dentener et al., 1999Dentener et al., , 2001;;G. Hosking, 2007;G. P. Hosking, 1979;Lester et al., 2000;Murray, 1973;Pawson et al., 2020;Pawson & Sky, 2009;Pawson & Watt, 2009;Reid et al., 2011;Romo et al., 2018).

A catalogue of insect species used as food in New Zealand, both past and present, is presented in (Andersen, 1933;Anonymous, 1922;Anteater, 2019;Best, 1902;Bodenheimer, 1951;Drummond, 1927aDrummond, , 1927bDrummond, , 1933;;Fiso et al., 2020;Magister, 1909;Meyer-Rochow & Changkija, 1997;Miller, 1952;Murihiku, 1931;Pond, 1994;Pycroft, 1929) Coleoptera Costelytra zealandica and/or Odontria zealandica Tūtaeruru, grass grubs Endemic Yes Wild Unknown Domestic Whole insect Adult (Best, 1902; Miller, 1952) Coleoptera Pyronota festiva Kerewai, kekerewai or reporepowa, mānuka beetle Native Yes Wild Unknown Domestic Whole insect Adult (Best, 1898, 1902; Drummond, 1927a; Meyer-Rochow & Changkija, 1997; Miller, 1952) Coleoptera Tenebrio molitor Mealworm, darkling beetle Non-native No Farmed Domestic/international Domestic Whole insect Larvae (Eat Crawlers, 2019) Coleoptera Zophobas morio Mealworm, superworm, superworms, king worms, morio worms Non-native No Farmed International Domestic Whole insect Larvae (Eat Crawlers, 2019) Hemiptera Kikihia muta Variable cicada, kihikihi kai Native Yes Wild Unknown Unknown Whole insect Unknown (Meyer-Rochow & Changkija, 1997; Miller, 1952; Stevens, 1930) Hymenoptera Polyrhachis sp. King, 2018; Mulligan, 2019) Orthoptera Anostostomatidae family, sp. unknown Wēta Native Doubtful Wild Unknown Unknown Traditional use seems unlikely, unconfirmed by any primary sources Adult, nymph (Crowe, 2002; O'Connor et al., 2023; Tucker, 2013) Orthoptera Nomadacris succincta Bombay locust Non-native No Unknown International Domestic Whole insect Adult, nymph (Eat Crawlers, 2019) Orthoptera Gryllus bimaculatus African field cricket, mediterranean field cricket Non-native No Farmed International Domestic Whole insect Adult, nymph (Eat Crawlers, 2019) Orthoptera Acheta domestica House cricket Non-native No Farmed International Domestic Whole insect Adult, nymph (Eat Crawlers, 2019) Lepidoptera Wiseana sp., Aoraia enysii Porina moth, forest ghost moth Native Possibly Wild Domestic Domestic Possibly referring to the "vegetable caterpillar" which is an entomopathogenic fungus Larvae (Crowe, 2002;Relph, 1991) which had several uses and is described as tasting nutty.
An aquatic insect:

Ephemeroptera, Megaloptera or, Plecoptera Sp. unknown, possibly Archichauliodes diversus Puene Unknown Possibly Wild Domestic Domestic In the Whakatane River: a little creature having six legs and eaten by children.

Larvae (Best, 1902;Miller, 1952) Huhu beetle -Prionoplus reticularis P. reticularis is mentioned as being a prized food item eaten raw or roasted after removal from rotting logs (Best, 1902(Best, , 1908;;Miller, 1952). When eaten raw, they were "eaten alive like an oyster, only the horny black head is bitten off and thrown away" (Anonymous, 1922) or roasted till brown and eaten as a delicacy (Andersen, 1933). Best (1902) mentions that two stages in the life cycle of P. reticularis are consumed, the larval stage (tunga rākau) and the final instar after feeding ceases and it undergoes a final moult in the pupal chamber (tātaka). The larvae feeds on several tree species found across New Zealand. It has been suggested that larvae extracted from different tree species have different flavour profiles for instance larvae found in matai timber are described as "distinctly sweet in flavour", whilst larvae from pine or macrocarpa have an "aromatic taste not at all unpleasant" (Anonymous, 1922). It is also recorded that Māori are familiar with the different flavours imparted on grubs by the timber it comes from, with miro being particularly prized (Pond, 1994). P. reticularis was frequently mentioned as a traditional food or delicacy in early newspaper articles and letters to the editor where they were described as being fat and greasy in texture (Drummond, 1933), "palatable and of a rich nut-like flavour" (Pycroft, 1929), and "tastes of hazelnut" (Andersen, 1933).

div.head: Pūriri moth -Aenetus virescens
div.p: A. virecens is a large moth whose larvae have been eaten as food. During part of the larval lifecycle, the insect forms a "7"-shaped burrow in the trunk of a host tree and spins a silk cover at the mouth of the burrow (Grehan, 1987b(Grehan, , 1987a)). To harvest the larvae, water would be poured into the burrow causing the larvae to exit the tunnel (Best, 1902). Best (1902) also mentions "a grub called mokoroa, which is found in the houhi and kai-weta trees, was eaten", likely referring to A. virescens, which is known to produce burrows in houhi (Hoheria populnea) and kaiwētā (Carpodetus serratus) trees (after the larvae leaves, these burrows become home to the wētā mentioned in the name kaiwētā (Wehi et al., 2020)).

Kēkerewai -Pyronota festiva & Tūtaeruru -Costelytra giveni P. festiva and Costelytra spp./Odontria spp. are scarabid beetles in the Melolonthinae subfamily. The adults of P. festiva are commonly found feeding on mānuka and kānuka whilst Costelytra and Odontria spp. are generalists. The larval forms feed on the roots of trees and pasture grasses and many species are considered agricultural pests.

It is generally P. festiva (kerewai, kekerewai) recorded as being used as food (Best, 1902;Drummond, 1927a;Miller, 1952). Best (1902) originally indicates that both kekerewai and tūtaeruru are a small green beetle (indicating P. festiva) but clarifies that tūtaeruru is a separate beetle that is also used as food. Miller (1952) suggests that tūtaeruru could be Odontria zealandica (now Costelytra giveni) due to its description by Best (1902) as flying in the evening with a distinctive booming noise. The beetles would be harvested in large quantities then ground up with the pollen of raupō and then steamed in a small basket and eaten (Best, 1902). It is interesting to note that cockchafer soup, a dish consumed in France and Germany, featured another beetle from the Melolonthinae family which was also an agricultural pest reaching high population densities (J. J. Schneider, 1844;van Huis, 2013).

div.head: Kihikihi kai -Kikihia muta
div.p: The variable cicada K. muta is a common cicada found from November to May on Carex sp. and Phormium sp. which are considered to be its hosts (Cumber, 1952;Logan, 2006). There are sparse records of its use as food with some references referring to it being mashed into a paste and used as food (Meyer-Rochow & Changkija, 1997;Miller, 1952;Williams, 1957).

div.head: Tīkopa/moka -Tortricidae family
div.p: Tortricidae is a family of Lepidoptera known as leaf roller moths. Best (1902) describes a caterpillar (moka), which was eaten, that draws leaves of plants closed around itself with silk matching the description of leaf rollers. Miller (1952) also mentions the edible moka and tīkopa (similar to moka but larger) as the larvae of the leaf-tying family Tineidae, however, I must presume that Tortricidae was meant as Tineidae are better known for eating fungus and fabrics.

Puene -An unknown aquatic insect Best (1902) describes a small, aquatic, six-legged creature called puene which is eaten by children. Miller (1952) advises that the term puene applies to larva of stoneflies, mayflies and the fish fly, Archichauliodes diversus.

Wētā -Anostostomatidae family I found only one reference to wētā being consumed in Crowe (2002). With the wētā being such an iconic insect in Aotearoa its consumption would be expected to have been recorded in some way in the grey literature. However, wētā were named as food by five participants in a recent survey of Māori (O'Connor et al., 2023). There has been contemporary use of wētā as food at the Wild Food Festival, where they have been served on crostini (Tucker, 2013). The name wētā can also refer to the Rhaphididophoridae, however there was no reference to this groups use in a traditional or contemporary setting.
Wiseana spp., Aoraia spp., Dumbletonius spp.

Porina moth (Wiseana spp.) is stated in Crowe (2002) as being eaten in the same way as huhu grubs. There were no references to this in other sources, however, some other moths in the Hepialidae family can become infected with Ophiocordyceps robertsii to become what was commonly called the "vegetable caterpillar" or āwheto/āwhato which was charred in a kiln and used as a dye for tā moko (Best, 1908;Pycroft, 1931). Some sources state that fresh vegetable caterpillars would be eaten and have a nutty taste (Crowe, 2002;Relph, 1991) whilst other sources stated that the vegetable caterpillar was not eaten (Pycroft, 1931).

div.head: Hīhue -Agrius convolvuli
div.p: A. convolvuli is a large moth in the Sphingidae family. The larvae are pests of kumara plantations, eating the leaves of the crop. The Te Aka Māori Dictionary lists anuhe, hīhue, āwheto and mūwharu as Te Reo names for A. convolvuli (Moorfield, 2023). Miller (1952) mentions that a grub called mūwharu was eaten and suggests that this is the larvae of the sphinx moth. A traditional pest control method for this species was to remove the insects and burn them in a fire as well as use smoke from burning leaves and karakia (Ehau-Taumaunu et al., 2020).

Recently, A. convolvuli has been investigated as an edible insect by Plant and Food Research Limited, a Crown Research Institute with food safety and nutritional analyses undertaken as well as taste tests (Pers. Comms.).

div.head: Locusta migratoria
div.p: Locusts, L. migratoria, are found in many parts of the country and have been farmed in New

Zealand for human consumption by Malcolm Diack of Otago Locusts (Nadkarni, 2022). The locusts are fed on freshly cut grass and reared inside shipping containers. Otago Locusts provides locusts for both pet and zoo animals and is certified with Ministry of Primary Industries to sell locusts to restaurants.

div.head: Teleogryllus commodus
div.p: The introduced black field cricket, T. commodus, is well known for their noisy night-time calls throughout New Zealand. They have been farmed in the Wairarapa by John Hart to produce cricket flour for making wraps (Mulligan, 2019;Skerrett, 2019;Walters, 2020). The crickets are grown in a controlled environment inside a shipping container with feed and oviposition material protected as intellectual property, Hart has also received Callaghan Innovation funding to investigate chitin extraction and health benefits from consuming cricket flour (Cricket Farming, 2020).
Vespula spp.

Perhaps one of New Zealand's more unusual exports were the excavated nests containing the larvae and pupae of Vespula wasps sent to Japan (Matsuura, 1999). New Zealand no longer appears to export Vespula however although there does appear to still be interest from Japan (Pers. Comms.).

div.head: New Zealand Lemongrass Ant -species unknown
div.p: The former edible insect company, Anteater, marketed an ant found in New Zealand that has the taste of "lemongrass & kaffir lime with a mild blue cheese aftertaste". The ant was foraged from the Canterbury region and sold to restaurants at a price point of $0.50 -$1.50 per plate (Anteater, 2019). Unfortunately, due to difficulties scaling up and getting products certified for export
Anteater have ceased trading (De Prospo, 2019).

div.head: Imported Insect Products
div.p: There are several insect products that are available for purchase in New Zealand, usually as shelf-

stable, processed goods. The products are often dried, processed into flour or included in novelty items such as chocolates and lollipops. Species included are mealworms (larvae of Tenebrio molitor), superworms (larvae of Zophobas morio); adult black ants (Polyrhachis sp.), African field cricket (Gryllus bimaculatus), house cricket (Acheta domestica) and, Bombay locust (Nomadacris succincta) (Eat Crawlers, 2019).

The Korean dish beondegi contains silkworm pupae and can be found canned in Korean supermarkets as well as in some Korean restaurants in Auckland. The dish is served as a stew in a stone pot with spring onions and chilli peppers (Tan, 2017).

div.head: Viable species for farming and other opportunities
div.p: Industrial scale production of insects was defined at the Expert Consultation Meeting organised by the FAO and Wageningen University in January 2012 as meeting a minimum reach of one tonne of per day of fresh weight insects (Vantomme et al., 2012). At the meeting, characteristics of a species that would make it suitable for industrial production were suggested to be ''a high intrinsic rate of increase (r m ) (short development cycle, high survival of immatures and high oviposition rate); a high potential of biomass increase/day (weight gain/day); a high conversion rate (kg biomass gain/kg feedstock) the ability to live in high densities (kg biomass/m 2 ); and low vulnerability to diseases (resistance)" (Vantomme et al., 2012). Other factors that are suggested to be considered are whether the species is amenable to process automation, if the species can be contained in non-native areas and whether there any ecological impacts if they were to be introduced outside of their natural range, potential for the species to be genetically improved through selective breeding and quantification of the ecological footprint and water requirements of the species (Vantomme et al., 2012). Within a New Zealand context, I would add that the cultural rights of indigenous peoples should be considered prior to industrial scale production being attempted.
Of the species that are native or adventive to New Zealand that could meet these criteria, Locusta migratoria, Teleogryllus commodus and Tenebrio molitor are the most suitable. L. migratoria and T.

commodus are farmed at various scales overseas already and both are currently being farmed in New Zealand (H. King, 2018;Mulligan, 2019;Nadkarni, 2022). Other New Zealand species may also be able to be farmed on a smaller scale (which can still be financially viable) but they are unlikely candidates for industrial production due to various aspects of their biology. Examples of these difficulties can be seen in the pūriri moth (A. virescens). A. virescens larvae have two distinct dietary phases, mycophagy and then phytophagy and a long life cycle of 3 -4 years (Grehan, 1987b;Grehan & Care, 2018) which poses challenges around diet formulation and the inherent low intrinsic rate of increase with such a lengthy life cycle.

In contrast to other possible endemic food species, there is a greater understanding of the biology of P. reticularis, a consequence of being a pest of forestry products (Alma & van Boven, 1975;Brockerhoff et al., 2006;Dentener et al., 1999Dentener et al., , 2001;;Hedley et al., 1979;Hood & Gardner, 2004;G. P. Hosking, 1979;Lester et al., 2000;Pawson et al., 2020;Pawson & Sky, 2009;Pawson & Watt, 2009, 2009). In the 1960's, John Edwards investigated the reproductive, larval, pupal, and adult biology as well as their host range and biogeography (Edwards, 1959(Edwards, , 1961b(Edwards, , 1961c(Edwards, , 1961d(Edwards, , 1961a(Edwards, , 1965)). Later, work by Rogers et al. (2002) investigated rearing larvae in the lab on an artificial diet and different temperature regimes. This reduced the larval life-stage from two years in the wild to c. 250 days in the lab, using a diet of Pinus radiata sawdust. While this research was originally conducted with the intention of better understanding a forestry pest, it has also formed a basis for further research into the viability of the species as a food source.

div.head: Characteristics of the New Zealand Edible Insect Marketplace Cultural context
div.p: In western cultures, the concept of eating insects frequently elicits disgust (Deroy et al., 2015).

Disgust towards eating insects appears to be a learned behaviour derived during childhood and seems to be particularly prevalent in Western consumers. These feelings of revulsion are generally attributed to differences in culture, that is, the prevalent practices, values and perceptions of a given time or place. In Aotearoa New Zealand, it has been suggested that for Western cultures, entomophagy and nose-to-tail eating practices (i.e. utilising all parts of the animal) carry connotations of low cultural status and subsistence lifestyles (Hoskins, 2007;Tucker, 2013). There is also some evidence to suggest that consumers from a Western background are more likely to perceive insects as vectors of disease (Curtis & Biran, 2001; G. C.
L. Davey et al., 1998;Prokop & Fančovičová, 2010).

The cultural values of individuals will be further influenced by dietary environment and the physical characteristics of the food in question (Hartmann & Siegrist, 2016). Specifically, the extent to which insects are commonly consumed and the range of species available. Insects are an unfamiliar food source for most European consumers and unfamiliar or rarely consumed food sources can alienate consumers that are less adventurous (food neophobic) (Jaeger et al., 2017;Pliner & Hobden, 1992).

In Aotearoa New Zealand's case, Prescott et al. (2002) found that consumers have significant concern for the "sensory appeal" of food which, combined with the absence of regularly consumed insects, may exacerbate the neophobia that consumers feel. Indeed, Tucker (2013) found in a small pilot study of young adults, that participants still reported feelings of revulsion at the idea of eating insects even though they could acknowledge the environmental benefits.
This challenge of overcoming revulsion remains a significant perceived factor for those trying to introduce insects to Western diets.

A commonly held view (P. Payne & Ryan, 2019) is that the more processed an insect is the more acceptable it is (i.e. flours, dyes etc.). However, at the Insects to Feed the World 2018 conference, a keynote presentation by Aspire Food Group indicated that the sale of whole, unprocessed insects has been surprisingly popular, which challenges this common view (Ashour, 2018). Hartmann and Siegrist (2016) found that people are willing to eat processed insect products and that people who have consumed processed insect products (in the form of cookies incorporating cricket flour) are more likely to consume unprocessed insects. Deroy et al. (2015) suggest that sensorially-driven strategies (such as name changes, focussing on texture, taste and visual presentation) combined with researchers teaming up with chefs and gastronomic experts will improve uptake by the public. This is an approach that was championed by the New Zealand start-up 'Anteater' which sourced insect ingredients from around New

Zealand and supplied insects only to chefs to ensure that the publics first experience with insects was a positive one. However, as discussed in the next section, this sensory focus is not one shared by the majority of New Zealand retailers of insects which appeal to consumers ideas of sustainability and the environment.

div.head: WAI262 -Ko Aotearoa Tēnei
div.p: While P. reticularis may represent a wedge facilitating the entry of insects into a mainstream diet, its status as a traditional food will most likely dictate the growth of that particular food.

Indigenous consumption of huhu grubs is an inextricable element of their marketing. In recent years huhu grubs have been included in the menu at the Wellington-based Hiakai restaurant, run by chef Monique Fiso, that champion Māori cooking and ingredients (Fiso et al., 2020) and cooked huhu grubs are also regular features at the Kawhia kai and the Hokitika Wild Food festivals.

The continued relationship between Māori and huhu beetles will require that any resulting The recommendations in the report are far ranging, many of which may need to be considered if commercialising a taonga species as food. Defining a taonga species is challenging. The language of the tribunal report limits this designation to species of flora or fauna in which an iwi, hapū, or whānau says it has a kaitiaki relationship, evidenced through a wide body of mātauranga Māori, whakapapa and kōrero. Meanwhile, for many Māori, "a 'taonga species' is simply any species which co-exists in their rohe, known or unknown" and the requirement to demonstrate a kaitiaki relationship is prohibitive (Potter & Māngai, 2022).

Of particular interest to the commercialisation of insects, the chapter on "the genetic and biological resources of taonga species" contains recommendations relating to bioprospecting, genetic modification, and intellectual property. Start-up companies often rely on the protection of intellectual property to attract investment. This can be achieved in several ways: copyright for creative works, trademarks for protecting brand identity, patents to protect an invention meeting specific requirements, plant variety rights (PVRs) to give sole rights to the dissemination of a new variety of plant, and trade secrets that protect something a company considers to be commercially valuable.

While Ko Aotearoa tēnei is not legally binding, in 2019, The Crown announced that it was developing a whole-of-government approach to the report. To date, this approach has included the commencement of the Plant Variety Rights Act 2022 to replace the previous one (PVR 1987). One of the purposes of the new act is ''to protect kaitiaki relationships with taonga species and mātauranga Māori in the plant variety rights system'' (Plant Variety Rights Act, 2022).

In this situation, "indigenous" (a native plant that occurs naturally, or has arrived naturally, in New Zealand) and "non-indigenous" plant species of significance (plant species brought to New Zealand before 1769 on waka from other parts of the pacific and are listed in schedule two of the legislation e.g., Kuru, Artocarpus altilis) are afforded additional procedures to recognise and protect kaitiaki relationships. The act creates a Māori Plant Varieties Committee to administer these procedures and enables the cancellation of PVRs that have adverse effects on kaitiaki relationships.

One of the recommendations in Ko Aotearoa Tēnei is the establishment of a Māori Advisory Committee (MAC) within the Intellectual Property Office of New Zealand (IPONZ) and this was included in the Patents Act 2013. Upon request, the MAC provides advice to the commissioner on whether an invention is derived from Māori traditional knowledge and, if so, whether commercialisation of that invention would be contrary to Māori values. However, the role is purely advisory and there is no requirement for the commissioner to action the advice (Patents Act, 2013).

The WAI262 report will have wide ranging implications for research and commercialisation however the full extent of this is not yet known. How The Crown gives effect to the recommendations made in the report remains to be seen, however, I suggest that it presents an opportunity to engage authentically with iwi to the benefit of all, whilst exploring developing insects as food outside of a traditional commercialisation model.

div.head: Food Sovereignty
div.p: The definition of food sovereignty has a complex history that is still not fully resolved (refer Patel, 2009). For our purposes, it can be understood as a precondition to food security, where food sovereignty is the right of peoples to determine their own food and agriculture systems and policies to provide good quality, healthy and culturally appropriate food. Indigenising food sovereignty is progressing this concept from an emphasis on rights to an emphasis on the cultural responsibility and relationships that indigenous communities have with their environment (Coté, 2016). The replacing of indigenous food systems with a globalised system of multinational companies has also resulted in a decrease in food sovereignty for indigenous cultures and an increase in diet related non-communicable diseases (Coté, 2016;Raschke & Cheema, 2008;Shirley, 2013). The importance of food sovereignty has been recognised by indigenous peoples as a means of decolonising land, reclaiming cultural identity and knowledge and securing health (Coté, 2016;Grey & Patel, 2015;Sweet Grass Consulting LLC, 2018).

Edible insects have been (and still are) an important resource for many indigenous peoples globally and there can be a deep understanding of insect species' life cycles, host plants and harvesting techniques embedded in traditional knowledge (Ramos-Elorduy, 2006). Colonial and neo-colonial forces have resulted in the loss of traditional knowledge and food habits (Raschke & Cheema, 2008) and customs around edible insects are no exception to this.

The food sovereignty of Māori has been adversely affected by British colonisation, land confiscation and urbanisation (Shirley, 2013) and regaining sovereignty of food production in a culturally appropriate way could lead to greater health outcomes and community resilience. In a Whakatāne pilot study, the importance of food sovereignty and security was highlighted. All participants interviewed highlighted the importance of access to food gardens, kaimoana and food from the bush, the revival of the practice of "growing, preparing and obtaining Māori kai"
and using this as a way of passing on traditional knowledge and practices (Moeke-Pickering et al., 2015).

The reclaiming of edible insects that are of cultural significance would contribute to the food sovereignty (and security) of Māori by (1) providing a source of animal protein and fat that complements other sources of kai, ( 2) fostering the retention of practices and knowledge involved in the collection of these species. This could be through wild harvesting of species, or in some cases, developing methods to domesticate or semi-domesticate a species. Farming is of interest to at least one iwi, with Ngāi Tahu having collaborated on a grant proposal with the now defunct company 'Anteater' and Crown Research Institute (CRI) Manaaki Whenua -Landcare
Research to develop a huhu grub farm (Newth, 2018).

div.head: Outline of NZ food standards and legislation
div.p: One of the major challenges faced by any prospective edible insect industries in the developed world is the absence of a clear and broad legislation which regulates manufacture and sale (van Huis et al., 2013). Food standards for both New Zealand and Australia are developed by Food
Standards Australia New Zealand (FSANZ), a statutory authority in the Australian Government Health portfolio, which operates under the Food Standards Australian New Zealand Act 1991.

The object of the Act is "to ensure a high standard of public health protection" through the FSANZ which aims to achieve, amongst other goals, a "high degree of consumer confidence in the quality and safety of food produced, processed, sold or exported from Australia and New Zealand (Food Standards Australia New Zealand Act 1991, pt 1 s3). This is primarily achieved through the review and development of standards for food available in Australia and New

Zealand which are set out in the Australia New Zealand Food Standards Code. In New Zealand, the Australia New Zealand Food Standards Code is enforced by the Ministry for Primary Industries (MPI) and public health units (Food Standards Australia New Zealand, 2019).

Insects as food (as opposed to insect-produced foods such as honey or shellac) do not fit comfortably into the Food Standards Australia New Zealand Act, or the Australia New Zealand Food Standards Code. Consequently, legislation regarding food safety for edible insects covers a small number of disparate products which fall under a range of headings including "farmed animals", "wild catch" and "extracts and additives". Approved colouring includes carmine/cochineal extract (INS number 120) which can be derived from scale insects or produced synthetically and can be included in food "at GMP" (Australia New Zealand Food

Standards Code -Schedule 16, S16-3), indicating "Good Manufacturing Practice" in which the amount of substance is limited to the "lowest possible level necessary to accomplish the desired effect" while also preparing and handling in the same manner as food ingredients (Australia New Zealand Food Standards Code -Standard 1.1.2 -Definitions used throughout the Code Section

Meanwhile, while standards for farmed animals are governed by the Food Standards Code which is applied across both New Zealand and Australia, the management of wild catch is managed by individual territories (of which one is New Zealand). Under the former, definitions of meat do include animals which have been explicitly "permitted for human consumption" and consist of skeletal muscle, fat, connective tissue, animal rind etc. (Australia New Zealand Food Standards

Code -Meat and meat products -Standard 2.2.1-2). Insects are not explicitly listed as a "meat", but the written definition certainly applies to them. In New Zealand, most insects listed as "farmed meat" would be imported, most notably from Thailand. By contrast there are clear provisions for the trade of wild harvested insects in New Zealand which are listed under the Animal Products Act (APA) 1999 which requires certification for the hunter or person supplying the meat.

FSANZ recently released the recommendations from the Advisory Committee on Novel Foods (ACNF) on a small number of insects (super mealworm, Zophobas morio; house crickets, Acheta domestica; mealworm beetle, Tenebrio molitor) deeming them both "non-traditional" with no history of human consumption in New Zealand or Australia, and "non-novel", with no safety concerns identified. An amendment was later added regarding recent evidence around allergenicity of crickets when consumed by a person with a crustacean allergy (Food Standards Australia New Zealand, 2019). As non-novel foods, they are not subject to limits on consumption or import (Reverberi, 2017). While the concept of "novel foods" are a tool by which regulatory provisions may be made for individual species, it may be a cumbersome process for small-scale producers (van Huis et al., 2013).

Cumulatively, this suggests that while there are precedents of farmed and wild caught insects being allowed for consumption and import, the approval process seems to be relatively ad hoc and approval for wild caught meat is likely to be a much easier prospect for potential businesses than farming.

div.head: New Zealand edible insect retailers and marketing practices
div.p: To assess how insects have been marketed in New Zealand, I collected publicly available text from edible insect companies' websites to identify the words which occurred most frequently in marketing. The text I used was taken preferentially from descriptions of the company and their mission statement. If the company only retailed one edible insect product amongst other food products, I used text from the product information. In one case, the company did not have a website and I collected text a profile written about the company in a local newspaper.

I used R and the tidytext package (Silge & Robinson, 2016) to prepare the text for analysis. A custom list of 599 stop words was compiled to remove words not relevant to insects or insect products (e.g., pronouns, articles, numbers). I made all nouns singular (so "insects" became "insect") and made abstract nouns and adjectives uniform (e.g., "environment", "environmental", "environmentally" became "environment"). I then quantified the top twenty most frequently used words and the top words used by all companies (Figure 1 A & B).

I identified eight (8) New Zealand based suppliers of edible insect products for human consumption that have been active within the last ten years (Table 3). Of these, five companies imported insect products/ingredients from overseas, two companies sourced insects locally, and one company both imported and sourced local ingredients.
Cricket powder or flour was the most common product, retailed by six of the eight companies.

For five of the companies, cricket powder or flour was their only edible insect product, sometimes sold alongside other food and health products. Of these five, two companies modified imported cricket flour to produce protein bars, nacho chips, wraps and protein powder for retail. When the origins of imported ingredients were available Canada, South-East Asia and New Zealand were most frequent, and farmed was the primary method of production. The large number of companies selling cricket flour or food enriched with cricket flour appears to coincide with the increased availability of cricket flour being produced globally from 2013 onwards (Reverberi, 2020). By 2023, however, only two of the eight companies are still actively selling insect products suggesting a lack of commercial success. This could be due to several reasons including, market size and saturation, price and availability of raw materials (particularly during the pandemic), low demand with consumers, or difficulties marketing insect products to the New Zealand public.

div.head: Figure 1. (A) The top 20 most frequently used words by New Zealand companies when marketing edible insect products. (B)
div.p: The number of companies using a particular word. The words "sustainable" and "protein" were used by all eight companies.

In Figure 1A, we see that the most frequently used words were descriptive of the product "cricket", "protein", "flour", "food" and "insect". The next most frequent words were "nutrition" and "sustainable", with the word "sustainable" being used by every company analysed (Figure 1 (B)). The heavy emphasis on words such as "sustainable", "environment", "greenhouse gas" suggests that the companies and products are marketed towards environmentally minded consumers. The environmental benefits of insect farming over conventional livestock are highlighted in marketing. However, cricket flour often originates from overseas farms (e.g., Canada, Thailand) and long-distance shipping could impact the environmental footprint of these products and cause claims of sustainability to be misleading.

It has also been suggested that highlighting the environmental benefits of edible insects is not enough to persuade people to buy (Deroy et al., 2015;van Huis & Rumpold, 2023). Tastiness and familiarity are important for consumers, particularly for a first encounter with an insect so incorporating into a familiar dish prepared by a professional chef may assist (Marquis et al., 2020;van Huis & Rumpold, 2023). This was particularly important to one of the companies, who would only sell their products to chefs to ensure the first experience of a consumer would be a positive one.

div.head: Concluding remarks
div.p: New Zealand, like many temperate regions, is often regarded as having a depauperate number of native/endemic species that are consumed. However, I have found that this is not the case, with at least eleven endemic or native species with a history of consumption. This is likely to be a conservative estimate as colonial and neo-colonial influence has possibly resulted in the loss of oral histories that contained knowledge of species used as food. These unique insects could be an exciting addition to our cuisine providing any commercial development is done collaboratively with, or led by, mana whenua. Wild harvest is likely to be the primary method of obtaining native insects, due to the long and/or complex life cycle of many of our species.
However, further research may lead to opportunities in optimising the rearing of P. reticularis which could allow for farming.

Marketing of edible insects as environmentally sustainable alternatives to other animal proteins would benefit from a life cycle analysis to ensure claims are accurate. It is likely that use of imported ingredients reduces the environmental benefits that could otherwise be obtained by using these products. Developing a domestic supply of cricket flour, with New Zealand's ready access to renewable energy and agricultural by-products, could also assist in meeting the environmental benefits promised by edible insects. However, the small market size could be the most restrictive element to the development of an edible insect industry. Producing insects for use as pet and livestock feed whilst developing the market for insects as food may be a way for companies to stay financially viable.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: The world's rapidly growing population, expected to reach over 9.7 billion by 2050 (United Nations, 2019), will increase the demand for animal proteins for food but also raises concerns for food security. Insects have been highlighted by the United Nations' Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) as an important source of dietary protein (van Huis et al., 2013) and, due to aspects of their biology, some insect species are a more sustainable option than sources of protein from livestock, poultry or seafood (van Huis & Oonincx, 2017). In Western countries, this has prompted investment in business start-ups seeking to farm insects to meet a perceived demand for insect protein and there is great potential for an increase in the use of insect protein globally.

Whilst over 1600 species of insects are used in the cuisine of many cultures around the world (van Huis et al., 2022;Van Itterbeeck & Pelozuelo, 2022), consumption of insects is perceived to be relatively novel amongst many consumers from Western countries. However, novel does not necessarily refer to the invention of a technology but to its introduction to a market (Siegrist & Hartmann, 2020). As the end users, and therefore paying customers of a product, consumers and their perceptions have an important role in the success of novel food technologies such as edible insects (Dunphy & Herbig, 1995;Verkerk et al., 2007).

Current research on consumer perceptions and acceptance of edible insects predominantly concentrates on northern hemisphere countries. Studies have consistently identified gender, food neophobia, disgust sensitivity, and prior insect consumption as general predictors of individuals' attitudes towards insects as a food source (Hartmann & Siegrist, 2016;Lensvelt & Steenbekkers, 2014;Orsi et al., 2019;Schlup & Brunner, 2018;Verbeke, 2015). Research has also shown that an existing awareness of edible insects positively influences consumer acceptance of insects as food (Barsics et al., 2017;Kostecka et al., 2017;Verbeke, 2015). Individuals who have tried insects in the past tend to exhibit a significantly higher positive attitude towards insects as food than those who have not (Wilkinson et al., 2018).

Generally, Western consumers are often associated with harbouring negative sentiments towards edible insects, although this perception can vary based on whether the insects are consumed whole, processed, or integrated into familiar food items. However, recent reviews caution against treating Western cultures as a homogeneous entity due to subtle and nuanced differences between various cultures and countries (Ardoin & Prinyawiwatkul, 2021;Mancini et al., 2019).

For instance, Central European and French Quebecers share similar views on edible insects but differ from those of English speaking North Americans (Hénault-Ethier et al., 2020), and earlyadopting Northern European countries like Finland and Sweden exhibit a more positive attitude toward insect consumption compared to Central European countries such as Germany and the Czech Republic (Piha et al., 2018). Countries with strong traditions of insect eating, such as Mexico, Peru and Thailand, are more willing to consume products containing insect powder, suggesting that cultures that already incorporate insects into cuisine are more accepting of novel insect products (Castro & Chambers IV, 2019; Hartmann et al., 2015). Studies investigating consumer acceptance in the Australasia region focus primarily on Australia (Bogueva & Schmidinger, 2019; Castro & Chambers IV, 2019; Chan, 2019; Lensvelt & Steenbekkers, 2014; G. Myers & Pettigrew, 2018; Sogari et al., 2019; Wilkinson et al., 2018) with two studies from New Zealand (O'Connor et al., 2023; P. Payne et al., 2023) and no studies from other Pacific Island nations. Australia and New Zealand present an interesting comparison as both are predominantly English speaking settler countries, share a legislative framework governing the use of novel food items including insects, a fledgling insect farming industry, and have Indigenous traditions of consuming insects (Food Standards Australia New Zealand, 2019; Lähteenmäki-Uutela et al., 2021; O'Connor et al., 2023; P. Payne et al., 2023).

Barriers impacting the acceptance of insects as a food source for Australian consumers include feelings of disgust, food neophobia, and concerns related to disease, unnaturalness, and threats to traditional perceptions of masculinity (Bogueva & Schmidinger, 2019;Castro & Chambers IV, 2019;Lensvelt & Steenbekkers, 2014;G. Myers & Pettigrew, 2018;Sogari et al., 2019;Wilkinson et al., 2018). Whilst the threat to masculinity experienced by male Australian participants is outside of the scope of this article, this has been explored in studies of plant based meat alternatives (Leary et al., 2023).

Disgust is a potent and universal emotion, prevalent in human societies. However, the specific objects or behaviours that trigger disgust are often culturally influenced, rooted in societal norms and moral values (Curtis & Biran, 2001). Food neophobia, closely related to disgust, represents the aversion to unfamiliar foods and has been identified as a key predictor of the acceptance of insects as a novel food source and it is also influenced by cultural factors (Hartmann et al., 2015; La Barbera et al., 2018;Verbeke, 2015). These traits, the evolutionary remnants of a defence mechanism, have historically helped reduce the risk of consuming poisonous or spoiled food (Curtis & Biran, 2001) and prevented the transmission of infectious diseases (Oaten et al., 2009).

In Western societies, insects are generally perceived negatively, often evoking feelings of disgust and fear (Kellert, 1993;Looy et al., 2014). Overcoming these deeply ingrained perceptions poses a considerable challenge to the acceptance of edible insect products.

To address these barriers, various strategies have been proposed. These strategies include normalising the consumption of edible insects by gradually increasing their visibility in everyday life, a process akin to 'public exposure therapy' (Koch et al., 2021). Additionally, emphasising the multisensory qualities of insects as food, often through collaborations with chefs and innovative culinary experiences like bug banquets, has shown promise (Deroy et al., 2015;La Barbera et al., 2018;Looy & Wood, 2006;Padulo et al., 2022). Incorporating insect-derived ingredients into familiar products, such as cricket flour in tortilla chips, has also demonstrated potential (Hamerman, 2016;Hartmann & Siegrist, 2016;Wilkinson et al., 2018).

A study of older Australian adults showed high levels of disgust with eating insects viewed as not being compatible with their cultural beliefs and values (G. Myers & Pettigrew, 2018). However, the strategies highlighted by participants to increase uptake are remarkably similar to those suggested in the literature. Strategies suggested include: disguising insects (concealing "animalness" by processing into a powder), ensuring safety through guarantees, inclusion on restaurant menus, instructions on cooking at home and utilising mass media to increase knowledge of the benefits of insects as food (G. Myers & Pettigrew, 2018). It has been demonstrated that being unwilling to eat insects does not necessarily mean being unsupportive of the research and development of an insects as a food industry (Ruby et al., 2015).

In New Zealand, texture, taste and disgust are perceived as barriers to insect consumption and the preferred way of consuming an insect was as a powder followed by frying the insect (P. Payne et al., 2023) which suggests that presenting the food in a culturally relevant context, such as incorporated into an existing food item (e.g. breads or pasta) or deep frying to avoid a texture that is not perceived to be pleasant (e.g., a "squish"). Demographic attributes that were found to impact willingness to consume insects included age and gender with participants in the age bracket 56 and above less willing to eat insects and males were significantly more willing to eat insects than females (O'Connor et al., 2023; P. Payne et al., 2023).

Several insect species have been used as traditional and contemporary sources of food in New Zealand, such as the huhu grub (Prionoplus reticularis), black field cricket (Teleogryllus commodus) and locust (Locusta migratoria). Current use of these insects relies on wild harvest in the case of the huhu beetle or farming in the case of black field crickets and locusts. There is occasional use of insects as ingredients in restaurants and in products available in supermarkets as well as features in the media on insects as food. Given the traditional use of insects as food and the consumer availability of insect-based products, it could be assumed that knowledge of insects as food is reasonably widespread and uncontroversial throughout Aotearoa New Zealand, however, this has not been quantified.

Understanding the drivers of consumer acceptance as well as consumer perceptions, knowledge, and use of insects in Aotearoa New Zealand is important to assist in the development of this sector as it grows. Using an online questionnaire and a mixed methods approach, I set out to quantify existing public knowledge of edible insect species, the beliefs and attitudes associated with insects as food, understand drivers influencing the likelihood of eating an insect in the future, and the sentiment attached to insects when seen as ingredients on a menu. I hypothesised

(1) prior experience of consuming insects and a greater knowledge of insects as food will increase the likelihood of being willing to eat insects in the future, (2) that negative words would be attributed to insects more than other food types.

div.head: Methods Participants
div.p: Participants were recruited via organic (shared by users of social media) and paid for (targeted adverts) social media posts. An anonymous, online questionnaire was designed using the online survey platform Qualtrics (v. August 2021, Qualtrics, Provo, UT). The questionnaire comprised five sections, (1) categorisation of participants; (2) knowledge and perceptions of edible insects;

(3) experience of eating insects; (4) likelihood of eating an insect or insect containing product in the future, and (5) demographic questions. The questionnaire used branch logic to conditionally present questions based on a participant's previous answers.

I received n = 735 responses to the questionnaire. Any responses that were indicated as spam (n = 3) or did not make it to the end of the questionnaire (n = 113) were discarded giving a total number of n = 620 for summary statistics. For the machine learning workflow, I removed any respondents who answered "prefer not to say" for any demographic questions (n = 60), leaving n = 560 for the logistic regression analysis. The median time taken to complete the questionnaire was 11.72 minutes (lower quartile = 8.88, upper quartile = 17.20).

div.head: Demographics
div.p: The demographic data collected were dietary preference, age, gender, ethnicity, country of birth, region of New Zealand, education, and income. For ethnicity data, answers were categorised into Level One groupings (European, Māori, Pacific Peoples, Asian, Middle Eastern/Latin American/African (MELAA), and Other Ethnicity). Where multiple categories were selected, I used a prioritised output (Māori, Pacific peoples, Asian, other groups except NZ European; and NZ European) (Ministry of Health, 2004). For dietary preference participants could write freely and these were then coded into six categories (omnivore, pescetarian, flexitarian, vegetarian, vegan, allergy/medical).

div.head: Existing knowledge
div.p: To investigate existing knowledge of edible insects, I asked participants "Can you list any insects that you know are used as food in Aotearoa New Zealand?". I quantified how many insects or insect products each participant knew as a count. Answers were grouped to a single common name to make consistent (e.g., huhu beetle, huhu bug, huhu grub and huhu larvae were grouped into huhu grubs). I categorised answers by insect order (e.g., Hymenoptera for ants, coleoptera)
and if a response referred to an organism or a product of an insect (e.g., insect flour, honey, cochineal) and presented in a table.

div.head: Likert Scales
