div.p: Likert scales were used to measure the impact of COVID-19 on the willingness to eat novel food items, future likelihood of eating an insect, food neophobia, specific beliefs and attitudes, and encouragement. A likert scale is a technique for the measurement of attitudes where a participant ranks how strongly they agree or disagree with a statement on an ordinal scale consisting of a 5
or 7 points (Likert, 1932;Sullivan & Artino, 2013). Where a scale was used in a previous study, I kept the original number of scale choices to enable comparisons.

div.head: Impact of COVID-19 on willingness to eat novel food items
div.p: To assess whether the Covid-19 pandemic impacted willingness to try an unfamiliar food ingredient, I used a 7-point likely-unlikely scale and asked the question "Imagine you are visiting a new restaurant, compared to pre-COVID-19, how likely are you to try a dish containing:" and presented with three items; (1) an unfamiliar ingredient, (2) an insect, (3) and an unfamiliar animal protein.

div.head: Future likelihood of eating insects
div.p: I asked all participants what their future likelihood of eating an insect was, creating two groups "likely" and "unlikely". Depending on the responses, I asked the reasons for this. For the unlikely group, the options were: allergic to shellfish/insects, religious reasons, dietary reasons, disgusted by insects, fear of insects, other (please specify). For the likely group, the options were:
sustainability/environmental benefits, price, health benefits, curiosity, cultural reasons, taste/flavour, other (please specify).

div.head: Food neophobia, specific beliefs and attitudes, and encouragement
div.p: Participants were categorised using the following scales: a food neophobia score (FNS) (ten questions with a likert scale from 1 to 7, then each score was added to give a value out of 70, higher scores indicate a higher degree of neophobia; adapted from Pliner and Hobden (1992)), specific beliefs and attitudes towards insects as food (nine questions with a likert scale of 1 to 5, covering themes of disgust, risk, benefits, ethics and naturalness (Ruby et al., 2015)), and attitudes towards the research and promotion of eating insects (two questions with a likert scale of 1 to 7 (Ruby et al., 2015)).

div.head: Word association
div.p: Word association is a widely used qualitative sensory technique in food science used to study consumer needs, beliefs and perceptions (Gambaro, 2018). It can allow access to emotions and motivations that may not be picked up using a quantitative scale. I used a word association exercise which asked, "You are reading a menu when you see the following ingredient in a dish, what are the first words or phrases that you think of?". One ingredient was presented at a time and in a random order. The ingredients were: lamb, locust, tofu, mealworm, beef, silkworm pupae, jackfruit, grasshopper, chicken, huhu grub, kumara, cricket flour, shrimp, and sky prawn (an alternative name for a locust). These ingredients fell into three broad categories of "conventional" animal, plant, and insect ingredients with the exception of sky prawn and silkworm pupae which were included to examine how participants respond to branding of an edible insect (sky prawn) and to the inclusion of an unfamiliar edible insect protein (silkworm pupae). The data were cleaned (e.g., removing punctuation, consolidating different spelling) using OpenRefine (v. 3.7.0), resulting in 18,808 responses consisting of 7405 unique words or phrases for analysis. Each word or phrase was attributed a sentiment (positive = 1, negative = -1, or neutral = 0).

div.head: Topics/Themes
div.p: To extract important themes from the word association data, I used term frequency-inverse document frequency (TF-IDF) (Salton & Buckley, 1988). TF-IDF is a technique used in text mining to suggest the topic of an individual document within a corpus (a collection of documents). In our context, a document was a specific ingredient in a menu item and the corpus was composed of all of the specific ingredients (see word association section for list of ingredients). TF-IDF is comprised of two parts, the term frequency (TF) and the inverse document frequency (IDF). Firstly, the term frequency is calculated within a document by counting the number of times a word or phrase appears within the document. Secondly, the inverse document frequency is calculated by dividing the number of documents by the number of documents containing a term and then taking the log of the output. This leads to terms that are unique to specific documents, indicating predictive power, being ranked highly, whilst terms common to all documents are given a lower ranking.

div.head: Thematic analysis
div.p: Thematic analysis was used to interpret the word association data following (Clarke & Braun, Virginia, 2021). This will be addressed in a separate paper.

div.head: Data Cleaning
div.p: The data were cleaned using R and Open Refine. Statistical analyses were conducted using R and R Studio (R Core Team, 2022; RStudio Team, 2022).

div.head: Statistical Analyses Sentiment Analysis
div.p: Sentiment analysis and term frequency-inverse document frequency (TF-IDF) was conducted using the tidytext package (Silge & Robinson, 2016). To assess whether there was a difference in sentiment between ingredient groups (animal, plant, and insects) and ANOVA was conducted with a post-hoc Tukey's Honest Significant Difference test used to assess differences between groups.

div.head: Machine Learning Model Selection
div.p: I used machine learning to empirically compare different models and select the best model to predict the outcome. The tidymodels metapackage is an ecosystem of packages that facilitate the construction and comparison of multiple models (Kuhn & Wickham, 2020). The R packages contained in this ecosystem were used for the machine learning analysis of whether likelihood of eating an insect in the future (likely/unlikely) is predicted by prior experience (yes/no), existing knowledge (number of edible insect species known), Food Neophobia Score (a score between 10 and 70), demographic data (education level, gender, and income). I removed participants who

div.head: Existing Knowledge
div.p: The median number of edible insects that could be listed was 1 (n = 223) followed by 2 (n = 168) and 0 (n = 122) (Table 6). The edible insect species and products identified by respondents are presented in Table 6. The most common species listed were huhu grubs (n = 333), followed by crickets (n = 298). COVID-19 Impact on Trying Unfamiliar Ingredients (Figure 2)

Participants were asked "Imagine you are visiting a new restaurant, compared to pre-COVID-19, how likely are you to try a dish containing:" and then presented the following options "an unfamiliar ingredient", "An insect", "An unfamiliar animal protein". The majority of respondents reported that they were more likely to try an unfamiliar ingredient, insect or unfamiliar animal protein than compared to pre-COVID-19 (64%, 47% and 46% respectively)

with the minority being less likely to try these items (10%, 27% and 28% respectively). With all options 26% of respondents stated they were neither more or less likely to try an unfamiliar ingredient, insect, or unfamiliar animal protein.

When responses were grouped based on those who had eaten an insect ('yes' group, n = 367) and those who had not eaten an insect ('no' group, n = 253), I found the 'Yes' group were much more likely to try an unfamiliar ingredient (70%, 58% and 54% vs. 55%, 35% and 32%) than not (4%, 17% and 19% vs. 18%, 41% and 41%) the neither more nor less likely category was largely the same between both groups (ranging from 24% -27%). Encouragement of Insects as Food (Figure 4)

In response to the question "We should encourage research on insects as food", the majority of participants agreed (89%). When responses were grouped based on those who had eaten an insect, this rose to 94% and when grouped by those who had not eaten an insect it decreased to 82%. In response to the question "We should support programs designed to encourage people to consume insects", the majority of participants agreed (78%). When responses were grouped based on those who had eaten an insect, this rose to 85% and when grouped by those who had not eaten an insect it decreased to 67%. Likelihood of eating an insect in the future (Figure 5)

Overall, the majority of participants were likely to eat an insect in the future (76%). When grouped by whether they had eaten an insect in the past, the majority of the 'Yes' and 'No' groups were likely to be willing to eat an insect in the future. The 'Yes' group, had a higher proportion of people who were likely to eat insects (88% vs. 60% in 'No'), and within the likely group, a larger proportion of participants indicated they were 'Extremely Likely' to try insects in the future. In contrast, in the 'No' group, there were a larger proportion of people who were unlikely to try insects (40% vs. 12% in 'Yes') and within this 'Unlikely Group' a larger proportion indicated 'Extremely Unlikely' to eat an insect.

div.head: Logistic Regression Model
div.p: I fitted a logistic model (estimated using ML) to predict future likelihood of eating an insect with prior experience, education, income, gender, food neophobia score and existing knowledge (Figure 6, Table 7). The model's explanatory power is moderate (Tjur's R 2 = 0.23). The model's intercept, corresponding to prior experience = no, education = diploma or certification, income = $10,001 -$30,000, gender = gender diverse, food neophobia score = 0 and existing knowledge = 0, is at 4.44 (95% CI [2.82, 6.28], p < .001).

The likelihood of eating an insect in the future was positively associated with having eaten an insect in the past (prior experience = yes; OR = 2.422, 95% CI [1.48, 3.99], p < .001) and existing knowledge (OR = 1.360, 95% CI [1.09,1.71], p = .007). The effect of food neophobia score is statistically significant and negative (OR = 0.912, 95% CI [0.88, 0.93], p < .001). All other terms were not statistically significant (Table 7). Note. OR = odds ratio; CI = confidence interval of the OR; LL = lower limit; UL = upper limit

div.head: Sentiment Analysis
div.p: When asked for the first words or phrases that come to mind when seeing an ingredient on a menu, all item groups received a similar number of mean responses per food item (animal = 1383.25, plant = 1376.33 and, insect = 1306.43). Neutral responses were the most common type of response across all groups. I found that food items in the animal and plant groups had more positive responses than negative, however this was reversed in the insect food item group (Figure 7). Words/phrases provided by participants for each food item were assigned a score: -1 for a negative sentiment, 0 for a neutral sentiment and 1 for a positive sentiment. These were totalled across each food group and divided by the number of items within each food group to provide the mean number of positive, negative, or neutral words by food group.

Insect ingredients were associated with a lower average sentiment than animal and plant ingredients (Figure 8A). I performed a one-way ANOVA to compare the effect of ingredient type (animal, plant or insect) on sentiment revealing a statistically significant difference in sentiment between at least two groups (F( 2 The distribution of sentiment scores for individual ingredients are presented in Figure 8B.

Within the insect group, cricket flour had the highest median sentiment score indicating a positive sentiment is associated with this ingredient. Both grasshoppers and huhu grubs had a neutral association with a median sentiment score of 0 and an interquartile range spread evenly either side of the mean, locusts and sky prawns also had a neutral median sentiment however the interquartile range is skewed towards the 25th percentile. Mealworms and silkworm pupae feature a negative association with a median score of -1 but with a skew towards the 75th percentile.

div.head: Words or Phrases Associated With Insect Products
div.p: In Figure 9, words that have the greatest discriminatory power are plotted for each insect ingredient. Different ingredients have clear differences in the words used to describe them, corresponding to the differences in sentiment seen in Figure 8B. When compared to animal and plant ingredients (Supplementary Figure 10 & Figure 11), I can see that insect ingredients tend to be less associated with food, and focus more on perceived physical properties of insects such as their movement or texture.

Words used to describe grasshoppers and locusts focused on physical characteristics ("green", "legs", "crunchy"). Grasshoppers do appear to have more positive associations ("cute", "jiminy cricket") than locusts and their possible role in food was mentioned ("flour"). Locusts were frequently described in negative historical terms ("swarm", "plague", "pest", "biblical", "Egypt")
suggesting they are associated with their impacts on human society and agriculture through history.

Huhu grubs were described by perceived flavour profile and texture ("peanut butter", "gooey", "creamy", "slimy"), their ecology ("native", "bush", "beetle"), their cultural significance ("Māori"). Broadly, the words used to describe huhu grubs were neutral or positive and fairly specific, reflecting their unique and culturally significant status as a food source in New Zealand.

Both mealworms and silkworm pupae had a median negative sentiment, and this is reflected in the words participants associated with them. Descriptive words, describing perceived movement or textural qualities featured heavily and were similar for both ingredients ("wriggly", "squishy", "crunchy", "slimy", "worm", "maggot"). There was also a focus on the human utility of these insects with the use of silkworms in textiles highlighted ("silk", "cocoon", "thread", "clothing")

and the use of mealworms in the pet industry ("pet food", "fish food", "bird food", "chicken food", "frog food", "lizards") however, neither ingredient was associated with human food with any frequency.

Sky prawns, a name used in the marketing of locusts, were largely met with confusion and unfamiliarity amongst respondents. The most frequent phrases associated with this ingredient were variations of "what is a sky prawn?". There was an association with familiar foods ("seafood", "prawn", "flying prawn", "crustacean") and some respondents correctly identified the ingredient as an insect ("locust", "cricket") however, there seems to be a general lack of recognition and understanding of the term.

On the other hand, cricket flour, which had a positive median sentiment score, was described using words that suggest it is perceived in a positive way ("curious", "interesting") as an environmentally friendly ("green", "environmental", and "alternative") and nutritious ("high protein", "gluten free") alternative to traditional flour. There appears to be associations between cricket flour and traditional culinary applications ("bread", "pancake," and "tortilla") suggesting that respondents associate this ingredient with foods. Discussion My research found strong support for insect consumption in New Zealand, in contrast to my findings on the viability of New Zealand edible insect businesses in the previous chapter. A majority of respondents had prior experience with insect consumption, expressing a willingness to continue eating insects in the future. Participants also possessed knowledge of edible insect species found in New Zealand, with huhu grubs and crickets being the most frequently mentioned species. Using a logistic regression model, several key predictors were influential in increasing the likelihood of future insect consumption, including prior experience with eating insects, familiarity with edible insect species, and a low food neophobia score (FNS). Factors such as gender, income, and education level did not appear to significantly influence individuals' likelihood of consuming insect-based foods. Despite this general openness to insect consumption, the analysis of the language used to describe insect ingredients reveals a contradiction; the average sentiment of the descriptors for insect-based ingredients was more negative than for plant or animal ingredients, with the exception of cricket flour which elicited more favourable associations.

Prior experience of eating insects was found to be an important predictor of future likelihood of eating insects, which was consistent with findings in the literature (Hartmann et al., 2015;Hartmann & Siegrist, 2016;Menozzi et al., 2017). Existing knowledge of edible insect species was also a significant predictor of future likelihood of eating insects. My findings suggest that New Zealanders are familiar with some edible insects, with huhu grubs and crickets both being frequently referenced by respondents. Familiarity has also been shown to be an important factor in food choice and it is commonly held that Western societies are unfamiliar with insects as food (Hoek et al., 2011;Verbeke, 2015). However, that does not appear to be the case in New

Zealand with a large number of participants able to name one or more species of edible insect (n = 498). Huhu grubs in particular were recognised by participants with 54% (n = 333) of respondents listing the huhu grub as an edible insect, reflecting the iconic status of this endemic species. Crickets were mentioned by 48% (n = 298) of respondents which is likely due to the high-profile crickets have received in both global and local media coverage of edible insects.

Unsurprisingly, a respondents' food neophobia score is negatively correlated with the likelihood of eating insects. It is likely that food neophobia is closely related to disgust (Hartmann et al., 2015), an emotion believed to have evolved to reduce the risk of disease, contaminants and poison (Oaten et al., 2009). It is difficult to overcome an emotional response using rational means although this can help in assuaging fears of sickness and disease (Jensen & Lieberoth, 2019). There is a significant cultural component to food neophobia which presents an opportunity to change people's perceptions towards insects as food over time through increasing public exposure (visibility of products in shops) and focussing on the sensory, gastronomic and marketing aspects of these products (Deroy et al., 2015;Koch et al., 2021;La Barbera et al., 2018). Frequently, insects as food are compared to caviar, lobsters, sushi and sashimi as foods which were once considered disgusting to many Western cultures but have since become popular (Koch et al., 2021;Ruby & Rozin, 2019), and it has been suggested that emulating the route-tomarket of sushi in the West could be an option for insect products (Cf. House, 2018). Given the importance of prior experience and existing knowledge in influencing individuals' openness to eating insects, educational tastings are one way to increase exposure to, and acceptance of, insects as food (Sogari et al., 2017). Employing a trained professional to cook the insects in a culturally relevant way whilst educating on the history and benefits of insects as food enables the first experience to be a positive one.

Despite most participants stating their approval towards insects as food, the word association exercise revealed an interesting contradiction; insect ingredients on a menu received a higher number of words with a negative sentiment than animal or vegetable ingredients. This suggests that there may be unconscious bias around insect ingredients and insects as food. Investigating the words people use when thinking about insects provides an opportunity to assess how people conceptualise insect ingredients and insects more broadly. By ranking words with the greatest discriminatory power for a food item (i.e., words that distinguished an insect ingredient from other ingredients), I found that insects evoke strong imagery with cultural, historical and biological contexts playing a clear role in shaping participants' perceptions of insects. For instance, locusts evoked Judeo-Christian references with: bible, plague, swarm, and Egypt; whilst references to children's movies (The Lion King and Pinocchio) appeared fairly often for huhu grubs and grasshoppers. Menu items that contained the term pupae or worm (silkworm pupae and mealworms) tended to evoke negative reactions. Also, responses were often not directly associated with food; instead being descriptive of the appearance, texture and movement of the insect (maggot, worms, larvae, moth, wriggly/wiggly, squishy, slimy), or their associated uses by humans (silk, clothing, thread, pet food, bird food, frog food etc.).

Cricket flour was the only ingredient with a mean positive sentiment score. The words that participants associated with cricket flour tended to match existing food concepts, for example; bread, pancake, tortilla, baking, gluten-free, and high protein. These are food items that either are associated with flour or are products containing cricket flour that have been marketed in New

Zealand. This supports previous research finding that processing an insect into a meal or flour is preferred by New Zealand consumers (P. Payne et al., 2023). Other words used to describe cricket flour related to sustainability such as: environmental, alternative, and green. Sustainability over other livestock and environmental benefits are an area that has been marketed heavily by companies selling cricket flour as shown in Chapter 1. Other words used to describe cricket flour indicated generally positive sentiments and acceptance as a food ingredient: interesting, curious, and no problem. Overall, the words participants used to describe cricket flour highlights the effectiveness of the marketing and media attention this product has received.

However, associating an ingredient with food does not guarantee that it will be well received. In the case of sky prawn, a marketing term used for locusts in New Zealand and overseas, the overwhelming response was of confusion (words and phrases that occurred with frequency were:

"what", "unknown", "no idea what this is", "never heard of it", "what is a skyprawn"). This indicates that the product has not achieved the same kind of public awareness as cricket flour and that attaching a word that is associated with food (i.e., prawn) is not enough to guarantee it will be well received. Providing more context would likely assist in alleviating feelings of distrust in this food product and it should be noted that the menu item was presented to survey participants without context. In a restaurant setting there would likely be access to further information (e.g., via the menu or waiter) and research has shown that being well informed reduces feelings of distrust (Schouteten et al., 2016).

Despite this, the use of "sky prawn" as a marketing device is a clever way of pointing out the morphological similarities between insects and crustaceans, which are already consumed, generally without issue. Indeed, at an evolutionary scale, insects are closely related to crustaceans, sitting within the clade Pancrustacea (Aleshin et al., 2009), and a recent review of the functional food properties of insects and shrimps, highlights that the shared phylogenetic history means that they should be viewed as terrestrial and marine counterparts with similar attributes and opportunities for exploration of novel functional food properties (Mishyna & Glumac, 2021).
Huhu grubs, which are a well-known edible insect in New Zealand (54% of participants identified huhu grubs as an edible insect), provide an interesting area to explore in the future.

Participants had clear associations between huhu grubs and food with preconceived notions (positive or negative) of flavours and textures mentioned frequently (e.g., peanut butter, gooey, creamy, squishy, slimy). Participants also associated huhu grubs with Māori culture, bush (a New

Zealand term for native forest) and native insects which suggests that there is a strong cultural association between huhu grubs and food in New Zealand. et al., 2023). Clearly there are opportunities for Māori-led businesses to develop and lead in this space and it would appear that there is a high level of acceptance of insects as food by Māori.

Indigenous groups reclaiming and promoting culinary practices to promote insects and other indigenous ingredients in an authentic way whilst preserving and reviving traditional harvesting techniques and knowledge should be supported and encouraged (Bermúdez-Serrano, 2020;

Reyes & Lessard, 2023). Restaurants such as Amazónico, in Colombia, and Hiakai, in New Zealand, are championing local culinary practices in contemporary dishes (Fiso et al., 2020;Taylor, 2023). At Hiakai, award winning chef Monique Fiso uses traditional ingredients, including huhu grubs, in her restaurant whilst also promoting the sustainable harvesting of ingredients according to tikanga (customs) (Fiso et al., 2020).

I measured participants specific beliefs and attitudes towards insects as food, finding that the majority of participants had positive attitudes towards insects as food, finding that the majority of participants agreed that insects were highly nutritious, good for the environment and are capable of feeling pain whilst disagreeing that eating insects is disgusting, unnatural or immoral and disagreeing that insects carry harmful microbes, toxins or increase the risk of disease. My findings contrast with those of Ruby et al. (2015) of American and Indian perceptions towards eating insects whose participants agreed that eating insects is disgusting, not natural for humans and that insects carry harmful microbes, whilst disagreeing that eating insects is good for the environment. This highlights there can be stark differences in perceptions between different cultures and lends support to avoid treating Western cultures as one homogenous entity (Ardoin & Prinyawiwatkul, 2021;Mancini et al., 2019).

Participants' agreement with the statement that insects are capable of feeling pain raises ethical considerations regarding the treatment of insects in farming and harvesting situations, an area that has received less research attention than other aspects of insect farming. Given a majority of participants agree (53%) or are uncertain (30%) that insects feel pain but disagree (67%) or are uncertain (22%) that it is immoral to kill them, it would be reasonable to assume that there is social licence to farm and kill insects but an expectation amongst the public that a duty of care towards the animal is taken into account when farming. Whether insects feel pain is an area still under debate and has implications for the development of welfare practices within the industry (van Huis, 2021). Similar discussions have occurred within the aquaculture industry regarding pain in fish, animal welfare and legislation and there may be opportunities to learn from these (Franks et al., 2021;Rose et al., 2014). However, farmers point out that applying codes of welfare from other sectors is unlikely to work directly with insects (Bear, 2019). There is difficulty in distinguishing nociception (the detection of noxious stimuli) and pain (the subjective experience of actual or perceived pain) empirically and so it would be best to approach the topic philosophically. The current landscape of insect welfare was recently summarised providing an excellent overview of the topic (van Huis, 2021), and a recent article investigated the complexities of care involved in insect rearing in New Zealand (Yee & Sharp, 2023).

Questionnaires as a research tool carries limitations which I have attempted to minimise but is still worth bearing in mind when interpreting the results. The sampling technique involved advertising on social media and snowballing which made it difficult to collect a representative sample of the New Zealand population and thus the results should not be generalised to the whole of New Zealand. Similar to a recent survey (P. Payne et al., 2023), this survey had a bias towards participants being European females with higher levels of education and higher income than would be expected from a representative sample of New Zealand. There are two potential sources of bias which are inherent in surveys: (1) social desirability bias where participants answer questions in a way they feel will be viewed favourably, which I hope to have minimised by having an anonymous questionnaire, and (2) the value-action gap where participants intentions are different to their actions (e.g., saying will eat insects in future may not translate to carrying through with this).

The value-action gap is a well-known phenomenon in sustainability research (Barr, 2006), and has been shown to influence the purchase of sustainable food products (Vermeir & Verbeke, 2006). Participants in my study expressed a willingness to consume insects, but the overall sentiment when describing insects was negative. When viewed alongside the limited viability of companies specialising in insects as food (discussed in Chapter 1) I suggest this may indicate a disconnect between value and action and that future research should prioritise this area.

In summary, my findings suggest that participants are accepting of insects as food with many having prior experience and some existing knowledge, which, along with a low neophobia score, predicted likelihood of consuming in the future. Despite this approval, an analysis of the language used to describe insects as food uncovered a nuanced contradiction where the sentiment of descriptors for insect ingredients were, on average, more negative than traditional meat or vegetable ingredients. However, the notable exception to this was for cricket flour which demonstrates the effectiveness of the marketing used for this product and lends support to the idea of processing insects to disguise their appearance. The specific beliefs and attitudes of participants towards insects suggest differences to how other cultures perceive insects as food and indicate that future research should be directed towards the welfare and ethics of insect farming. I conclude by suggesting that future development of edible insects in New Zealand should build on the existing awareness of crickets and huhu grubs to leverage off existing acceptance and the unique history of these insects as food in New Zealand.

div.head: Figure 11. Term frequency -inverse document frequency (tf-idf) plots for plant ingredients, showing the words most frequently used to describe an ingredient. A) kumara, B) tofu, C) jackfruit
Introduction
div.p: The "fingerprinting" of food products has been used to protect consumers from food fraud, confirm the provenance of a food, and identify indicators of quality or functional properties of value (Capozzi & Bordoni, 2013;Ellis et al., 2016;Mialon et al., 2023). Fingerprinting involves characterising a food at the molecular level and recent advancements in high-throughput omics technologies and multivariate statistics has allowed this to be done at lower costs and greater accuracy (Capozzi & Bordoni, 2013). There are four major categories of omics: genomics, transcriptomics, proteomics, and metabolomics; of these, metabolomics is the most frequently used for fingerprinting. Metabolomics identifies and quantifies the metabolites within a biological sample, where the metabolome is strongly shaped by biological origin, biotic and abiotic conditions the sample is exposed to, and any treatments or processing experienced post-harvest (Sobolev et al., 2017).

A variety of metabolomic spectroscopy techniques have been applied to identify fraudulent products including: Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy, near infrared (NIR) spectroscopy, Raman spectroscopy, nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy, and mass spectrometry (MS) (Ellis et al., 2016). Mass spectrometry is a technique that detects and measures the mass-to-charge (m/z) ratio of charged ions of volatile or, following derivatization, semi-volatile metabolites (Dunn, 2008). The advantages of mass spectrometry are its incredible sensitivity, capable of detecting compounds in µM concentrations, and its ability to identify and detect known and unknown compounds based on mass spectra (Dunn, 2008). Frequently, mass spectrometry is coupled with gas or liquid chromatograms (GC & LC respectively) to further increase the sensitivity of the technique (Dunn, 2008). Metabolomics provides a useful technique to analyse a wind range of different characteristics of an insects biology (Poma et al., 2022;Snart et al., 2015). To date, fingerprinting research on edible insect species has focused on using technologies such as polymerase chain reaction (PCR), proteomics, FTIR and MS, to differentiate between species (Belghit et al., 2019;Debode et al., 2017;Dhami et al., 2011;Francis et al., 2020;Marien et al., 2018;Mellado-Carretero et al., 2020;Tramuta et al., 2018;Zagon et al., 2018). In other non-insect contexts, due to the high precision and ability to distinguish a wide range of metabolites, metabolomics has been used in the detection of food fraud and geographical provenance (Capozzi & Bordoni, 2013;Mialon et al., 2023;Sobolev et al., 2017).

Food fraud is a broad term that refers to a food item being misrepresented for economic gain through deliberate and intentional substitution, addition, tampering, the misrepresentation of food, food ingredients or packaging (Spink & Moyer, 2011). The risk of food fraud increases when there is high demand for a product, the product is expensive and when there are complex supply chains involved (Black et al., 2016). Recent examples of this have propelled food fraud into global headlines, 24 % of dried oregano in the UK was found to be adulterated, olive oil has been mixed with lower quality oils, and the widespread sale of horsemeat as beef in the European market caused public outcry (Azadmard-Damirchi & Torbati, 2015; Black et al., 2016;Brooks et al., 2017;Tibola et al., 2018). Metabolomics has been used to distinguish wild vs.

farmed sea bass, and Kopi Luwak (coffee that has been pre-digested by the Asian palm civet) from imposter coffees (Ellis et al., 2016;Jumhawan et al., 2013;Vidal et al., 2014). A variety of metabolomic techniques have been applied to insect products to ascertain their ability to detect between different insect species in powdered forms, which are an obvious candidate for food fraud (Mellado-Carretero et al., 2020;Tata et al., 2022).

Attempts to determine the geographical provenance of a food product have also become more prevalent with the introduction of protected geographical indication (PGI), protected designation of origin (PDO), and traditional specialities guaranteed (TSG) statuses by legislative bodies. Metabolomics presents a useful way of investigating the variability of metabolites found within different geographical populations of an edible insect species as it is relatively cheap compared to genomic and proteomic analysis and has been used to successfully discriminate the geographical origin of tea, rice, hazelnuts, honey, mussels and snapper fish (Azevedo et al., 2017(Azevedo et al., , 2017;;Ch et al., 2021;Drivelos et al., 2021;Goode et al., 2020;Klockmann et al., 2016;Peng et al., 2023;Rochfort et al., 2013).

Increasing demand for a food product can lead to unintended outcomes such as placing pressure on wild food species through the unsustainable harvesting of wild organisms or the adulteration of food for commercial gain (Spink & Moyer, 2011;van Huis & Oonincx, 2017). This can pose a risk to human health, consumer trust and the population viability of wild organisms. Whilst edible insects are enjoyed in many countries around the world, demand for edible insects in Western nations has increased since the publication of a 2013 FAO report, proposing insects as a more sustainable alternative to livestock (van Huis et al., 2013). Generally, this demand has been satisfied through the farming of insects, such as crickets and mealworms. These are usually sourced from domestic or international production and legislative constraints on what can be sold as food in Western countries restricts the use of wild insects. There has been discussion
around the flavour of wild harvested insects being superior to farmed insects (Evans et al., 2017, p. 179), and demand for wild insects for gourmet use is likely to increase over time.

In many countries around the world, insects are wild sourced and an increase in demand could place undue strain on populations already experiencing challenges with climate change, habitat loss and pollution (van Huis & Oonincx, 2017). This has occurred in some countries with an existing history of eating insects. Whilst insects have been sustainably harvested for generations by indigenous peoples with an intimate knowledge of the life cycle and ecology of the species, there is evidence that changes in environment, the impact of human development, urbanisation, along with growing demand for insects from outside of these communities, is putting insect populations at risk (van Huis & Oonincx, 2017). Mexico, a country with a rich history of insect use, many of which are highly sought after, provides a useful case study. Ramos-Elorduy (2006) studied the use of 30 edible insect species over a 25 year period in the village of Tulancalco, Mexico. In this village, there have been changes in the population demographics over several generations where people have moved from villages to cities. There are still strong ties to the food culture, and this drives high prices for insects for sale in the city.

This demand for insects is fulfilled by outsiders who are not familiar with the traditions and deep ecological knowledge held by villagers and now, of these 30 species, 14 are threatened and at risk of local extinction (Ramos-Elorduy, 2006). There are other examples of wild populations of edible insects that are no longer sustainable to harvest due to a variety of pressures, including crickets belonging to the genus Oxya in Asia, aquatic hemipterans in Mexico and India and the larvae of Lepidoptera in Africa and Australia (Badillo-Camacho et al., 2015; Parsons, 2010; Ramos-Elorduy, 2006; Samom, 2016; van Huis & Oonincx, 2017). Whilst the causes of decline in these species are multi-faceted, it is possible to reverse population loss and restore the sustainability of wild harvest. For instance, an increase in pesticide use in farming has led to a decrease in the populations of Oxya spp. crickets in Korea and Japan which has resulted in a reduction in their use as food (C. L. R. Payne, 2015;Pemberton, 1994). However, when farmers in areas of Korea moved away from pesticide use, the Oxya spp. populations returned and their use as a food saw a revival (Pemberton, 1994).

Given the suitability of harvesting an insect population can vary geographically, is there a way to ascertain if an edible insect comes from a specific geographic region within a country? This would allow consumers, legislators, or importers to confirm an insect comes from a region where it is sustainable to harvest from and thereby make an informed decision.

Metabolomics would appear to be an ideal candidate for this as the metabolome of an organism is intricately shaped by its biology and the environment it inhabits. Several New Zealand studies have explored using metabolomics to characterise the metabolomic profile of native and endemic New Zealand species, showing that the geographical location and environmental factors experienced influence the metabolomic profile of the organism. In a study of scale insects in New Zealand, Dhami et al. (2011) found that the metabolite composition of honey dew varied between species, sites and host tree suggesting that geographic location alone is not the sole driver of differences between metabolite profiles. Goode et al. (2020) investigated the metabolome of snapper Chrysophrys auratus (prev. Pagrus aurata) from different harbours around New Zealand finding that differences in amino acids were attributable to turbidity of their environment, an aspect known to be a stressor resulting in suboptimal physiological responses.

Temperature is another important environmental variable that is known to impact the metabolism of organisms. In New Zealand, metabolites have been identified that can be used to detect thermally stressed green-lipped mussels (Perna canaliculus).

The endemic cerambycid longhorn beetle, Prionoplus reticularis, better known as the edible huhu grub, is an ideal candidate to explore the effect of geography and latitude on variation of metabolomic profiles. The species is found throughout Aotearoa New Zealand from Northland to Stewart Island and the larvae infest rotten logs of several different host plant species, including Pinus radiata (radiata pine). P. radiata accounts for 90% of New Zealand's forestry stock and is found across New Zealand (Beets et al., 2012), which allows for an assessment of geographic variation in metabolites in huhu, while controlling for a consistent diet.

I used GC-MS (gas chromatography -mass spectrometry) to investigate the relative abundance of metabolites in the huhu grub (Prionoplus reticularis) collected from Pinus radiata, along a latitudinal gradient the length of New Zealand. I investigated (1) variation in metabolites and lipids of huhu between individuals and locations, (2) whether metabolites of huhu show a trend along a latitudinal gradient, and (3) if FAAs, FAs & sugar metabolites can be used to 'fingerprint' an individual to a geographic location.

div.head: Methods
div.p: Fieldwork I sampled larvae (n = 144) of P. reticularis during a three-week period, from the 7th November to 29th November 2020, at six locations along a latitudinal gradient within New Zealand (Figure 12). At each site, logs of similar decomposition were selected. The diameter of the log was measured using a tape measure and temperature within the log was recorded with a thermocouple (TM-902C, Shenzhen Glory Line Co., Ltd.). The log was then split open, and any larvae of P. reticularis removed. Larvae were weighed on a portable jewellery scale (8028 Series, Guangzhou Juanjuan Electronic Technology Co., Ltd.), wrapped in aluminium foil and frozen in liquid nitrogen before placing in a -80 °C freezer upon return to the lab. At each location a sample size of 24 larvae were collected, except for Seabush (n = 23) and Mangaroa (n = 25). -50 -45 -40 -35 -30 165 170 175 180 Longitude Latitude

div.head: Metabolite extraction and derivatisation
div.p: Metabolite chemical extraction and derivatisation of P. reticularis larvae was achieved using methyl chloroformate (MCF) and trimethylsilyl (TMS) protocols developed at The University of Auckland (Smart et al., 2010;Villas-Bôas et al., 2011;Zarate et al., 2017). The methods are outlined briefly below.

div.head: Extraction of metabolites
div.p: Samples were placed in a freeze-drier for a 48-hour period then macerated with a glass rod. A 10 mg (±2 mg) amount was placed in a 1.5 ml Eppendorf tube and the remainder of the sample was stored in a -80 °C freezer. I added 500 µL of 50 % cold MeOH:H2O, resuspended the solute using a vortex and froze using dry ice. I then centrifuged at -9 °C at 3500 rpm for five minutes.

The supernatant was transferred to 2 mL microcentrifuge tubes. The extraction process was then repeated on the supernatant with 500 µL of 80 % cold MeOH:H2O. The pellet from the 1.5 mL Eppendorf tube was retained for biomass measurement. For MCF, the internal standard was D4alanine (20 μL, 10 mM) TMS, the internal standard was D-ribitol, (20 μL, 10 mM). The extracts were dried in a Speed-Vac Concentrator with a Refrigerated Vapor Trap (SC250EXPP2-115, Thermo Scientific, New Zealand) for 4 hours at 0.8 HPa, ramp 3-5, with no heating. Once dried, the samples were kept in a desiccator overnight prior to derivatisation.

div.head: Methyl chloroformate Derivatisation
div.p: I followed the modified MCF derivatisation method outlined in Smart et al. (2010). In brief, I added 400 µL of 1 M sodium hydroxide to the derivatisation blank, standard amino acid mix and each sample and then vortexed to resuspend the freeze-dried samples. 334 µL of methanol and 68 µL of pyridine were added to individual silanised tubes, the corresponding sample was then added. I added 40 µL of methyl chloroformate to each sample, vortexing for 30 seconds and then adding a further 40 µL and vortexing again. 400 µL chloroform was added and then the sample was gently vortexed for 10 seconds. 800 µL sodium bicarbonate solution (50 mM) was added and then vortexed for 10 seconds. I then centrifuged the samples at 2500 rpm for 5 minutes. The aqueous phase was removed using a vacuum, and anhydrous sodium sulphate added to remove any residual water. The samples were then transferred to a glass GC-MS vial with glass insert and lid.

Each day I randomly assigned seventeen MCF derivatised samples to a GCMS run for a period of nine days. Each GCMS run also included a chloroform vial, an alkane mix vial, one blank vial, one standard mix containing reference amino acids at 0.5 mM and three quality controls (containing pooled samples).

div.head: Trimethylsilate Derivatisation
div.p: I derivatised sugar metabolites using the protocol outlined in Zarate et al. (2017). Samples were removed from the desiccator and 80 µL of methoxyamine hydrochloride in pyridine (2g.100 mL)

was added before vortexing for 1 minute to dissolve the dried sample. Samples were then transferred to glass GCMS vials and incubated for 90 minutes at 28 °C. I then added 80 µL Nmethyl -N-(trimethylsilyl trifluoroacetamide (MSTFA) and incubated for 30 minutes at 37 °C.

Each day I randomly assigned sixteen TMS derivatised samples to a GCMS run for a period of nine days. Each GCMS run also included a chloroform vial, an alkane mix vial, one blank vial, two standard mix containing reference amino acids at 0.5 mM and two quality controls (containing pooled samples).

div.head: GCMS
div.p: To analyse the metabolite profile, I followed the protocol outlined in Villa-Bôas et al. ( 2011) using an Agilent GC 7890A coupled to a MS 5975C (Agilent Technologies, Santa Clara, CA, USA) with a quadrupole mass selective detector (electron ionization) with a split/splitless inlet.

The GC oven was held at 45 °C for 2 minutes then increased at a rate 9 °C a minute to 180 °C where it was held for 5 minutes before increasing at 40 °C per minute to 220 °C and held for 5 minutes before increasing 40 °C per minute to 240 °C where it was held for 11.5 minutes before increasing at 40 °C per minute to 280 °C where it was held for 10 minutes. The mass spectrometer interface was set to 250 °C, the source was set at 230 °C and the quadrupole was set at 150 °C. 1 µL of sample was injected into the column using splitless mode and the carrier gas was ultra-high purity helium (BOC Ltd.). The mass spectrometer was set to scanning mode with a start time of 4.78 minutes and a mass range of 38 -550 atomic mass units and the detection threshold of 50 ion counts.

div.head: Data Preparation
div.p: I used the MassOmics pipeline developed at the University of Auckland to process the raw spectra using Automated Mass Spectral Deconvolution and Identification System (AMDIS, v2.66) (Aggio et al., 2011). Agilent Chemstation was used to create a subset of the Wiley and NIST Libraries. Then the identification output was merged in the MassOmics R package to make a library which was converted to an AMDIS compatible format using the Lib2Nist converter. For the MCF analysis, I merged both the NIST library and in-house libraries. For the TMS analysis, I used the in-house library. I then used AMDIS to deconvolute and identify compounds in each sample with the output of this converted into a summary report in R. I curated the summary report using excel and R following the protocol outlined in Guo et al. (2017). Prior to analysis I normalised the data by sample biomass and the internal standard (MCF = D4-alanine; TMS = D-ribitol).

div.head: Data Analysis
div.p: I used MetaboAnalyst (Pang et al., 2021;v. 5.0) and R to analyse the data. The MCF data and TMS data were analysed independently of each other using the following procedure. First, any zero or missing values were imputed using 1/5 of the minimum positive value for each variable.
The data were then normalised using log10 transformed and pareto scaled (mean centred and divided by the square root of standard deviation of each variable).

To assess variation in the metabolic profiles of individuals and locations, I used hierarchical clustering analysis to produce a dendrogram of clustered metabolites, with Euclidean distance as the similarity measure and Ward's linkage as the clustering algorithm and presented the results as a heat map.

I used the pattern hunter analysis in MetaboAnalyst to identify metabolites that correlated best with a latitudinal gradient running from north to south. Pearsons R was used for the correlation coefficient, and the top 25 metabolites that increased or decreased linearly with the latitudinal gradient are presented as a bar chart.

I conducted a principal component analysis (PCA) to assess the variance in the data set by reducing the dimensionality of the data by summarising into scores, a weighted average of the original variables. The output of this was presented as pairwise score plots for the first five principal components, as a two-dimensional plot of the first two principal components and as a three-dimensional plot visualising the first three principal components.

To confirm if the separation by location visible in the PCA plots were statistically significant, I used a type I permutation multivariate analysis of variance (PERMANOVA) on the Euclidean dissimilarity matrix of each data set (M. J. Anderson, 2001). The PERMANOVA was performed using the R package 'vegan' (Oksanen et al., 2022) with n = 10,000 permutations. I then performed pairwise comparisons on significant terms to compare between different groups. P values were adjusted using the Benjamini-Hochberg procedure.

To assess if I could classify a random huhu grub sample to the location it was sampled from, I used a random forest (RF) supervised machine learning algorithm to construct a classification model. RF is suited to high dimensional data, where there are a high number of features (metabolites/compounds) to samples (Acharjee et al., 2016). RF uses random feature selection from a bootstrap sample of each branch to create an ensemble of classification trees from which class prediction calculated from a simple majority vote. As RF is prone to overfitting (Fawagreh et al., 2014), data were split into a training set of 2/3 and testing set of 1/3 to calculate out-ofbag (OOB) error and a confusion matrix. A variable importance measure was also calculated by measuring the increase in the OOB error when a metabolite is permuted whilst all others are left the same. I Implemented this through the 'randomForest' R package (Liaw & Wiener, 2002) via MetaboAnalyst.

div.head: Results
div.p: A total of 144 samples, representing six geographic locations along a latitudinal gradient, were extracted with two derivatisation methods. Using GCMS, I identified 146 compounds (including 39 'unknown' metabolites) comprising a variety of fatty, amino, and organic acids, and sugar and sugar alcohols and other compounds. Of the 146 compounds identified, 103 were derivatised using MCF and 43 were derivatised using TMS. As the two datasets contain relative abundances to different internal standards, I analysed each separately and present them individually.

div.head: Methyl chloroformate
div.p: I present the 10 most abundant compounds (using untransformed data) identified by MCF in Figure 13. The remainder of analyses presented use data that has been normalised.

Using a heatmap, I explored variation in the MCF derivatised metabolite profile of the edible insect P. reticularis between individuals and locations (Figure 14). There was a large amount of variation in the metabolite abundance between individuals, and no visually distinct patterns between locations.

I found that several metabolites exhibited a weak correlation along a latitudinal gradient. The top 25 metabolites that correlate with a latitudinal gradient are presented in Figure 15. Of these 25 metabolites, only two were significant after correcting using FDR: unknown compound 117 showed a weak positive correlation (r = 0.30, p = 0.01) and unknown compound 198 showed a weak negative correlation (r = -0.27, p = 0.04) with latitude (Figure 15).

I constructed an unsupervised PCA model for the MCF dataset which showed the general structure of the data (Figure 16). For the MCF dataset, the first two principal components cumulatively explain 64.8 % of the total variation (PC1 explains 53.9%, PC2 explains 10.9%).

When visualising in two-dimensions (Figure 16 & Figure 17), I was able to see some grouping in relation to location although there was a lot of overlap between groups. However, when visualising this in three-dimensions (Figure 18), a greater degree of separation between locations was visible.

The PERMANOVA results (Table 8) showed that location played a significant role in the metabolite composition of P. reticularis, explaining 12.3 % of the variation observed in the data set (p < 0.001, R 2 = 0.123). Larval weight was also significant but only explained 5 % of the variation (p < 0.001, R 2 = 0.05). The log the larvae was sourced from and temperature of the log were also significant, explaining 9.3 % of the variation and 1.4 % of the variation respectively (p = 0.03, R 2 = 0.093; p = 0.05, R 2 = 0.014). I performed pairwise comparisons among locations of origin to understand which locations significantly differed from one another (Table 9).
The classification model (using random forest algorithm) had an overall out-of-bag (OOB) error rate of 0.319, meaning the model correctly identifies the location of a sample 68.1 % of the time.

Kaingaroa had the greatest OOB error rate of all sample locations with 0.42 (Table 10, Figure 19). I also used a random forest model to determine metabolites that have the greatest impact on the accuracy of the model and could be used as biomarkers in the future (Figure 20). These 15 metabolites accounted for a mean decrease in accuracy of 16.7% when permuted in the model, with the top 5 metabolites accounting for a 7.2 % decrease in accuracy. Trimethylsilyl dataset I present the 10 most abundant compounds (using untransformed data) identified by TMS in Figure 21. The remainder of analyses presented use data that has been normalised. I discovered several metabolites that exhibited a weak correlation along a latitudinal gradient. The top 25 metabolites that correlate with a latitudinal gradient are presented in Figure 23. Of these 25 metabolites, only four were significant after correcting using FDR with 2-(methoxyimino)pentanedioate showing a weak negative correlation (r = 0.35, p < 0.001), arabinose showing a weak negative correlation (r = -0.31, p = 0.003), phosphoric acid showing a weak negative correlation (r = -0.29, p = 0.005), and urea showing a weak negative correlation (r = -0.24, p = 0.04) (Figure 23).

Using a heatmap, I explored variation in the TMS derivatised metabolite profile of P. reticularis between individuals and locations (Figure 22). There was less variation in the metabolite abundance between individuals when compared to the MCF heatmap (Figure 14), and some visually distinct patterns emerged between locations, in particular Mangaroa & Seabush both exhibited lower abundances of metabolites that other locations.

I constructed an unsupervised PCA model for the TMS dataset which showed the general structure of the data (Figure 24). The first two principal components cumulatively explain 62.1 % of the total variation (PC1 explains 46.1 %, PC2 explains 16 %). When visualising in twodimensions (Figure 24 & Figure 25), I was able to see clearer groupings in the TMS data set in relation to location than compared to MCF. When visualising in three-dimensions (Figure 26), a greater degree of separation between locations was apparent.

The PERMANOVA results (Table 11) confirmed my PCA observations, showing that only location played a significant role in the metabolite composition of P. reticularis, explaining 31.1 % of the variation observed in the data set (p < 0.001, R 2 = 0.311). I performed pairwise comparisons on the location factor to understand which locations significantly differed from one another (Table 12).
The classification model (using the random forest algorithm) had an overall out-of-bag (OOB)

error rate of 0.278, meaning the model correctly identifies the location of a sample 72.2 % of the time. Again, Kaingaroa had the greatest OOB error rate of all sample locations with 0.58 (Table 13, Figure 27). I also used random forest to determine metabolites that have the greatest impact on the accuracy of the model and could be used as biomarkers in the future (Figure 28). These 15 metabolites accounted for a mean decrease in accuracy of 33.4 % when permuted in the model, with the top 5 metabolites accounting for a 15.2 % decrease in accuracy. Table 12. Pairwise comparisons between locations for TMS metabolites. All P values were corrected using the Benjamini Hochberg correction. Figure 27. Cumulative error rates of the random forest classification model for metabolites identified with TMS over 5000 permutations.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: Ascertaining the provenance of an edible insect would allow for identification of products that have been sourced from geographical areas where an insect population might be under threat. I assessed the viability of an untargeted, GC-MS based approach to fingerprinting an edible insect, the larvae of P. reticularis, using two different derivatisation techniques. I used an untargeted GC-MS approach to create a metabolomic profile of 144 P. reticularis samples from six geographic locations along a latitudinal gradient. I identified 43 compounds using TMS derivatisation and 103 compounds using MCF derivatisation for a total of 146 compounds. I found that a RF model trained using the TMS derivatised metabolite profile had the highest accuracy, predicting the correct location of a sample 72.2 % of the time. In comparison, a RF model trained using the MCF derivatised data set had an accuracy of 68.1 %. I found that samples from one location, Kaingaroa, had a much lower accuracy in the model regardless of the derivatisation technique, suggesting that individuals sampled from this population had variable metabolite profiles that overlapped with that of other populations. Despite this, the PERMANOVA analysis found Kaingaroa to be significantly different from all other sites, except for Cheney's in the MCF data set. Whilst the RF model performed reasonably well, there is room for improvement. Future research comparing different classification models would assist with this. For example, models such as soft independent modelling by class analogy (SIMCA), support vector machine (SVM)

and linear discriminant analysis based on principal component analysis (PCA-LDA) yielded similar if not better results in the finger printing of hazelnuts (Klockmann et al., 2016) There was considerable variation observed in the metabolomic profiles between individuals in the MCF data set (predominantly amino acids, fatty acids and organic acids) and there was little visible distinction between locations in the heatmap. I saw less variation between individuals in the TMS derivatised samples (predominantly sugars and sugar alcohols) and, visually, I was able to see some distinction between locations. This distinction was also visible in the PCA and was confirmed with PERMANOVA, with location explaining a greater amount of the variance in the TMS data than in the MCF data (31.1 % vs. 12.3 %). This suggests that TMS may be a better derivatisation technique than MCF for assessing differences between populations of P. reticularis.

I found several compounds whose relative abundance correlated with a north-south latitudinal gradient. Of particular interest were arabinose and urea, which are related to gut and metabolic activity. Urea is a nitrogenous waste product of metabolic processes in insects and arabinose is a five-carbon sugar that can be converted by gut bacteria into essential aromatic amino acids (Scully et al., 2013(Scully et al., , 2014)). Both compounds had a negative correlation as latitude increased (i.e., became more southerly), and I propose that this relates to the activity levels of the insects along these gradients. The most southerly field sites, Flagstaff (Dunedin) and Seabush (Invercargill), were visited at the beginning of November, when it was still very cool, and the larvae were noticeably sluggish indicating a lack of feeding activity and most likely a lowered metabolic rate.

There are few studies investigating metabolomic variation along natural gradients. Arabidopsis lyrata ssp. petraea, a plant, has been shown to have significant natural variation in metabolism between locations, and exhibit adaptations to cold that are population specific along a latitudinal gradient (M. P. Davey et al., 2008Davey et al., , 2009)). A decrease in the concentration of essential amino acids as latitude increased was found in a range-expanding mite, Tetranychus urticae, which was suggested to be due to reduced exploitation of resources at the margin of the organisms range, with lower feeding rates resulting in lower concentrations of EAA (Van Petegem et al., 2016).

Mannose and trehalose are two compounds with low molecular weights that are important for freeze tolerance in insects. Both of these compounds were found in high relative abundance in the samples. Larvae were collected over the course of November, a period where larval activity would be increasing following diapause. Cessation of diapause is believed to occur as mean temperatures increase (Edwards, 1961b;Rogers et al., 2002). For Auckland, there is evidence this occurs around August and presumably later in the year at lower latitudes (Edwards, 1961b). Cold hardiness is likely to be important to the survival of diapausing P. reticularis, particularly in southern locations where below freezing temperatures can occur and this may explain the high levels of mannose and trehalose. The concentration of low molecular weight sugars and sugar alcohols has been shown to differ in concentration between geographical localities in another cerambycid species, suggesting that this may be linked to environmental temperature (Feng et al., 2014). Curiously, the P. reticularis larvae collected from the most southerly field site, Seabush, had the lowest levels of mannose and trehalose which is the opposite of what would be expected if these compounds are important for freeze tolerance.
Proline, followed by alanine, were the most abundant amino acids found in the larvae of P.

reticularis. Many insects are capable of oxidising proline for use as a fuel and most beetles use a combination of proline and carbohydrates for flight, whilst some beetle groups exclusively use proline for flight (Auerswald, 2000;Gäde, 1997aGäde, , 1997b;;Gäde & Auerswald, 2002;Teulier et al., 2016). In laminine cerambycids, both proline and glycogen are used by flight muscles (Gäde & Auerswald, 2000). When proline is used by flight muscles, it undergoes partial oxidation resulting in the production of alanine which is then stored in the fat body and then used to re-synthesise proline (Gäde & Auerswald, 2002). It is likely that the high abundance of these two amino acids is related to their importance in the metabolism of the larvae, and storage of these compounds will be important for the adult life stage which does not feed.

Future research could investigate how the metabolome varies temporally and with diet. The metabolomic fingerprint of a grub is likely to vary over time. It would be logical to next investigate how the metabolome alters at different stages of the season and life cycle, such as selecting larvae before, after and during diapause. This would help to validate the use of fingerprinting in assessing geographic provenance, whilst also providing insights into how the metabolome changes during different aspects of the life history of this species. I controlled for diet by only collecting larvae from pine logs, however, it is commonly held that the taste of P.

reticularis is "sweeter" when it has come from a matai log (pers. comms.). This suggest that diet may alter the compounds attributable to flavour in the larvae and presents an interesting future direction for research.

In summary, this study used an untargeted GC-MS method to characterise the metabolomic profile of P. reticularis along a latitudinal gradient. By utilising two derivatisation techniques, MCF and TMS, I was able to identify metabolites comprised of amino acids, organic acids, fatty acids, sugars, and sugar alcohols, and from these profiles predict which location a larvae came from with reasonable accuracy, with the TMS data set providing the greatest accuracy. I found compounds that correlated with a latitudinal gradient, offering insights into how environmental cues influence the metabolism of P. reticularis. Further investigation is required into the pattern I observed in sugars implicated in freeze tolerance, trehalose and mannose, which did not follow the environmental gradient I expected. Proline and alanine were prominent amino acids identified and this is likely indicative of their importance in the metabolism of both larval and adult life stages. This preliminary study presents opportunities for future research such as investigating a temporal gradient and the role of diet on the metabolomic fingerprint of this species.
Chapter 5 The static allometry of traits associated with fitness in Prionoplus reticularis (Coleoptera: Cerambycidae)

div.head: Abstract
div.p: Scramble competition mating systems are characterised by intense competition among males to locate and mate with females. Despite the prevalence of scramble competitions in nature, little is known about how selection influences male traits important for scramble competition, and their patterns of sexual dimorphism and allometry. The mating system of the cerambycid Prionoplus reticularis exhibits the hallmarks of a scramble competition so I set out to determine the degree of sexual dimorphism and patterns of allometry in traits predicted to be important in scramble competition: body size, wing size and antennal size. I also assessed the influence of body size and wing traits on locomotory performance in male huhu using a flight mill. I observed pronounced sexual dimorphism between male and female individuals across all measured traits, with the exception of wing aspect ratio. Female traits were consistently larger on average than males, with the exception of the antennae. Male antennae were significantly larger on average than female antennae which suggests sexual selection has generated longer antennae but smaller body size in males. I did not observe positive allometry for any male or female traits. Females showed negative allometry in antennal length, wing aspect ratio, and wing loading whilst all other traits exhibited isometry. In contrast, all male traits demonstrated negative allometry, except for wing loading which was isometric. This suggests that whilst sexual selection is likely driving sexual dimorphism, larger males do not benefit from disproportionate investment in wings or antennae.

Instead, stabilising selection likely generates the negative allometries of traits I observed, possibly due to biomechanical constraints. In the three areas of flight performance I explored, I discovered that wing loading was significant and positive, suggesting that as wing loading increases, so too does flight distance, duration and speed. This result suggests that relatively heavier males may have the energetic reserves to fly faster and for longer, contrary to studies of other taxa. Overall, I highlight the study of patterns of trait investment in scramble competitors as a potentially fruitful avenue of further research.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Scramble competition mating systems are characterized by intense competition among males to locate and mate with females, then continue to move through the environment investing in mate acquisition rather than defence (S. T. Emlen & Oring, 1977;Herberstein et al., 2017;Thornhill & Alcock, 1983). Such mating systems often involve little courtship, but high levels of multiple mating by both males and females, and therefore a high degree of sperm competition. Mating systems dominated by scramble competition are likely to be very common in the animal kingdom (Herberstein et al., 2017). Despite this, the way that selection influences male traits involved in scramble competition is less well-understood, than for more dramatic mating systems such as leks, and those that involve male defence of females or their critical resources (Emberts et al., 2023;M. Fea & Holwell, 2018;Fiske et al., 1998;Palaoro et al., 2022;Walker & Holwell, 2018). Among these more well-studied mating systems, significant research attention has focused on sexual dimorphism, allometry and the selective benefit of male signals, conspicuous ornaments, and exaggerated weaponry (Bonduriansky, 2007;Bonduriansky & Day, 2003;Eberhard et al., 2018;McCullough & O'Brien, 2022). In contrast, less is known about how selection influences male traits important for scramble competition, and their patterns of sexual dimorphism and allometry.
Due to the importance of locating mates, sometimes over long distances, strong selection on sensory traits in males is predicted under scramble competition (Thornhill & Alcock, 1983).

Darwin predicted that sexual selection should influence the evolution of the 'organs of sense' in much the same way as for ornaments and weapons (Darwin, 1871;Elgar et al., 2019). He proposed that males with sense organs better able to detect females should find and mate with more females and these traits would be selected for. This is particularly the case among scrambling species and higher investment in the size and sensitivity of male sense organs such as eyes, ears and antennae has been demonstrated for many species (reviewed in Herberstein et al., 2017). For example, most male moths show longer and more elaborate (pectinate) antennae than females (Symonds et al., 2012), and the number and density of olfactory antennal sensilla have been shown to be higher for males in a wide range of insect species including mantises, beetles, stick insects, flies and moths (Holwell et al., 2007;Jourdan et al., 1995;Mark et al., 2018; S. S. Myers et al., 2015;F. Zhang et al., 2021). Eyes can also be sexually dimorphic, with male Bibionid flies having larger eyes than in females, all the better to detect the females against complex backgrounds (Nordström & O'Carroll, 2009;Zeil, 1983). Evidence for a functional relationship between sensory trait size and mating success or the ability to locate mates is however, rare. Where it has been established, research has shown that male Pseudomantis albofimbriata (Mantodea) with more trichoid sensilla (a chemosensory sensilla) were able to find females quicker (Jayaweera & Barry, 2017) and Uraba lugens (Lepidoptera) males arriving at a trap containing a single female had on average larger antennae compared to a trap containing two females indicating that larger antennae provided an advantage in finding weaker sensory cues (Johnson et al., 2017).

Just as males who can better detect females will be selected for under scramble competition, those who can move more quickly or cover wider distances in search of females, are predicted to have higher mating success (Able, 1999;Andersson, 1994;Husak & Fox, 2008). Locomotion and investment in locomotory traits are known to differ between males and females, often to extremes such as in cases where females are sedentary (e.g. many spiders, Grossi & Canals, 2015) and lack means of dispersal (e.g. flightless female mantises (Barry et al., 2011), moths (Niitsu et al., 2017) and stick insects (Zeng et al., 2020) when compared to more mobile and winged males.

Giant wētā are one of the best studied groups with males with longer legs relative to their body size being more mobile resulting in higher mating success (Kelly et al., 2008). In dragonflies, sexual selection has been shown to act on flight endurance rather than speed with larger wings and increased fat reserves leading to greater endurance and higher mating success (Gyulavári et al., 2014).

In flying species, the morphology of wings are correlated with performance allowing wing metrics, such as aspect ratio and wing loading, to be used as predictors of locomotive ability (Berwaerts et al., 2002;Gibb et al., 2006). Aspect ratio is a metric that represents the relationship between length and width (or area) of a wing, with a high ratio characterized by a longer, thinner wing suited to fast, agile flight (e.g. dragonflies), and a low aspect ratio indicating a shorter, broader wing suited to slow gliding flight (e.g. butterflies) (Fu et al., 2014;Le Roy et al., 2019;Wootton, 2020). Wing loading describes the relationship of body mass to wing area with the energy efficiency of flight increasing as wing loading decreases (Gibb et al., 2006). In noctuid moths, individuals reared in a nutrient poor environment display developmental plasticity with lower than predicted body weights and lower wing loading ratios suggesting an adaptive response tailored to lowering the energetic costs associated with flight (Angelo & Slansky, 1984).

Body size is more complex and it seems that how scramble competition influences male body size depends on its relationship with locomotion (Andersson, 1994;Ghiselin, 1974). In a scramble competition mating system, an individual's reproductive success may be impacted by traits such as energy efficiency, endurance, mobility, manoeuvrability, agility, and aerial ability. If body size interacts with these traits, then selection pressure will lead to sexual size dimorphism (SSD) where one sex will be smaller or larger than the other. For small male SSD, several hypotheses have been put forward to explain this phenomenon. The Ghiselin -Reiss small-male hypothesis proposes that smaller males have an advantage in mate searching as they require less energy per unit of time of mate searching and therefore require less time having to replenish energy through foraging and can spend more time searching for mates (Ghiselin, 1974;Herberstein et al., 2017;Reiss, 1989). This has been documented in the water strider, Aquarius remigis, where smaller males had greater mating success in a food limited environment (Blanckenhorn et al., 1995). In species where smaller or lighter males might benefit from increased locomotor speed or endurance (e.g. flying species, spiders that climb to females), it is predicted that selection will reduce male body size relative to that of females, and relative to locomotor traits such as wing area and leg length (Crompton et al., 2003;Gyulavári et al., 2014;Moya-Laraño et al., 2002;Vollrath & Parker, 1992).

In species where larger bodied males can move faster or have more energy reserves to cover more distance or roam for longer periods, then larger bodies are likely to be selected for. For example, in some spider species, larger males are associated with greater mating success (Brandt & Andrade, 2007;Foellmer & Fairbairn, 2005) which is suggested to be due to a locomotor advantage on horizontal substrates (Brandt & Andrade, 2007), whilst in the cerambycid Phoracantha semipunctata, larger males are able to walk faster and have a greater antennae span, leading to higher mating success through covering a greater area during mate searching (Hanks et al., 1996).

Allometry is the study of the scaling relationship between a trait of interest and body size. It has been broadly classified into ontogenetic, evolutionary and static allometry. Ontogenetic allometry encompasses changes in trait and body size over different developmental stages, evolutionary allometry refers to the relationship between body and trait size among species, and static allometry (henceforth referred to as allometry), refers to how a trait correlates with size among individuals of the same developmental stage and species (Klingenberg & Zimmermann, 1992).

Allometry is represented as the mathematical expression 𝑦𝑦 = 𝑏𝑏𝑥𝑥 𝑎𝑎 which relates a trait of interest, 𝑦𝑦, to a measure of body size of an organism, 𝑥𝑥, with the y-axis intercept represented as 𝑏𝑏 and the slope, of particular interest to evolutionary biologists, estimated as 𝑎𝑎 (Huxley, 1924).

The slope of the line can be classified as being positively allometric (𝑎𝑎 > 1), negatively allometric (𝑎𝑎 < 1), or isometric (𝑎𝑎 = 1) (Huxley & Teissier, 1936). This is of interest when considering how the size of a trait of interest, for example antennae, scales between with body size amongst individuals of a species. If, after measuring a sample of individuals, I find that the relationship between antennal length and body size is greater than one (i.e. 𝑎𝑎 > 1), this is described as positive allometry and I can infer that larger individuals are investing disproportionately in that trait in comparison to smaller individuals.

Many traits under sexual selection have been shown to exhibit positive allometry. Both ornaments and weapons frequently scale positively with body size in males, but not females (Dale et al., 2007;D. J. Emlen, 2008;Rico-Guevara & Hurme, 2019; but see Bonduriansky, 2007). In contrast, genitalia and sexually selected contact structures involved in courtship show negative allometry, due to the functional constraints of successful male-female interaction (Eberhard, 2009;Eberhard et al., 1998). It is unclear how sensory and locomotory traits under sexual selection will scale with body size. The pattern of allometry for any traits represents the variation in the marginal fitness gains that individuals of different sizes receive by investing more or less in those traits (Bonduriansky & Day, 2003). Therefore, for sensory or locomotory traits, if larger individuals stand to gain fitness benefits from investing in the development of disproportionately larger antennae or wings, then I would predict positive allometry to evolve.

However, there are likely to be strong functional and biomechanical constraints that curtail exaggeration. For example, larger wing length or area is likely to only provide additional locomotor performance up to a point, where mobility would then be reduced with further exaggeration (Frankino et al., 2005;Rayner, 1988). Such constraints might drive the evolution of negative allometry, or lead to no deviation from isometry.

The huhu beetle, Prionoplus reticularis (Cerambycidae: Prioninae), is an iconic New Zealand long horned beetle whose larvae feed on the dead and decaying wood of certain native and exotic tree species (Edwards, 1959). The sex ratio of adult beetles is roughly 1:1, however light trapping is biased towards male capture (Edwards, 1956(Edwards, , 1961c)). The adult beetle is large, short lived and non-feeding, living for around two weeks upon the energy reserves accrued from its two to three year xylophagous larval stage (Edwards, 1961b(Edwards, , 1961c)).
