Upon emergence, the female produces a male attracting pheromone setting up the conditions for a scramble competition mating system where males try to find spatially dispersed females to mate with within a finite time period determined by their energy reserves. There is also a report of P. reticularis males engaging in combat displays with other males, where the display escalates through several stages to grappling with the fore legs until one individual is thrown onto its back (Edwards, 1961c).

I set out to (1) determine the degree of sexual dimorphism in measures of body size, wing size and antennal size for P. reticularis., (2) determine the patterns of allometry for sensory (antennae length, ninth flagellomere length), locomotory (wing length, wing area, wing aspect ratio and wing loading) and combat (tibia and femur) traits for P. reticularis and, (3) assess the influence of body size and wing traits on locomotory performance in huhu using a flight mill. Specifically, for

(2) I predict that positive allometries indicative of sexual selection will exist in male traits optimized for detecting females quickly (chemosensory structures i.e., antennae), traits that improve male mobility (locomotory traits i.e., wing size including wing aspect ratio and loading)
and positive selection on traits that improve combat ability in males (grappling ability, i.e., femur and tibia length of fore legs).

div.head: Field site and Collection
div.p: I collected adult huhu beetles (n = 112) from Riverhead Forest, Auckland, New Zealand using a mercury vapour light at night between November 2021 and February 2022. Individuals were stored in ventilated plastic specimen jars with a piece of cardboard for beetles to gain purchase and rest. Upon return, each individual had half a staple super glued to the pronotum which allowed for easy attachment to flight mill via a magnet. To identify each individual, a number was written on the left elytron using acrylic paint (Molotow Extra Fine 1mm Pen). Individuals were acclimatised in the dark at room temperature for 1 hour before being attached to flight mills. The weight of each individual was taken before attachment to a flight mill using a milligram scale (8028 Series, Guangzhou Juanjuan Electronic Technology Co., Ltd.). After flight mill tests (see below), individuals were then placed into a freezer and traits of interest were dissected, attached to graph paper and digitised using a flatbed scanner (HP Envy 5000 series).

div.head: Measurements of Morphological Traits
div.p: Traits of interest were measured using ImageJ (NIH, 1.50i). The locations of linear measurements taken is visualised in Figure 29. I measured total body length (from mandibles to tip of left elytron, mm), pronotum width (between two pairs of pronotal spines, mm), femur length (along ventral edge, between proximal bend and distal femoral spur), tibia length (along ventral edge, between proximal bend and distal tibial spur), antennal segment length (pedicel, scape, flagellomere 1 to 9), total antenna length (sum of antennal segments), elytron length (from base of integument to distal end of medial suture) and hind wing length (henceforth called wing length, humeral plate to distal end of radial anterior 4), wing area (calculated by tracing the wing edge in ImageJ and measuring area). For wing aspect ratio (2(𝑤𝑤𝑤𝑤𝑤𝑤𝑤𝑤 𝑙𝑙𝑙𝑙𝑤𝑤𝑤𝑤𝑙𝑙ℎ) 2 / 𝑤𝑤𝑤𝑤𝑤𝑤𝑤𝑤 𝑎𝑎𝑎𝑎𝑙𝑙𝑎𝑎) and wing loading (𝑤𝑤𝑙𝑙𝑙𝑙 𝑏𝑏𝑏𝑏𝑏𝑏𝑦𝑦 𝑚𝑚𝑎𝑎𝑚𝑚𝑚𝑚/2(𝑤𝑤𝑤𝑤𝑤𝑤𝑤𝑤 𝑎𝑎𝑎𝑎𝑙𝑙𝑎𝑎)), I doubled the wing area and wing length to account for only measuring a single wing. All measurements were taken from the right-hand side of the insect where possible (if damaged, the left-hand side was used).

div.head: Flight Mill Design
div.p: Six flight mills were constructed and attached to a microprocessor (Arduino Uno Revision 3) to record flight information (Figure 30). A 3D printer was used to produce the shaft and arms of each flight mill from polylactic acid (PLA). The axis upon which the flight mill arm pivots was comprised of a polyethylene pipette tip inserted into a 0.5 ml polyethylene Eppendorf tube, this material has very low friction, allowing for the arm to rotate freely (Figure 30 B). The flight mill arm was placed over the Eppendorf tube. To extend the length of the arms, stiff paper clip wire was attached to either end. To allow for ease of attachment specimens, a neodymium magnet was attached to the end of the extended flight mill arm which would then be attracted to the half-staple attached to the pronotum of the beetles (Figure 30 D). At the end of the opposite flight mill arm, a plasticine counterweight of the specimen was attached (Figure 30 A).

Each flight mill had a hall effect sensor (Honeywell 2SS52M Omnipolar Hall Effect Sensor) coupled with a 10K ohms pull-up resistor and 5V power supply attached to the shaft (Figure 30 E). On the flight mill arm, close to the axis, a neodymium magnet was secured with epoxy resin, close to the centre of the axis (Figure 30 C). Each flight mill was connected to the same microprocessor using single core, flexible flat cable. A high precision real time clock (RTC) module was connected to the microprocessor along with a micro-SD card reader module. The microprocessor was programmed using Arduino programming language, a C++ variant. The schematics for the electronic components are presented in Supplementary Figure 33.

Upon each rotation of the flight mill arm, the magnetic field of the neodymium magnet causes the hall effect sensor to complete an electrical circuit, sending a signal to the microprocessor to record the flight mill identification number (1 -6) and time (both UNIX and POSIX format) to a text file on the micro-SD card. For example, if a rotation was completed on flight mill three at 0013h on the 26th of January 2022, it would be recorded as follows:

div.head: Data Processing
div.p: Flight mill data were cleaned using R 4.2.3 (R Core Team, 2022) and the tidyverse ecosystem (H. Wickham et al., 2019). I attached n = 103 P. reticularis to flight mills, producing 4,018,162 data points from n = 68 individuals. Firstly, I removed any data points that had been recorded with an incorrect date stamp i.e., occurring outside of the experimentation period (44 data points). I then grouped all responses by date and time and summarised to provide the number of revolutions per second (rps), providing 176,121 data points. In some instances, an individual would cease flying over the top of the hall-effect sensor, causing the sensor to stay in an on position, leading to abnormally high revolutions per second. To account for this, I filmed five individuals (n = 5) and recorded maximum revolutions per second, taking the highest value (1.6 rps), I then doubled this value and filtered out any results greater than 3 rps resulting in a final amount of 23,876 data points for analysis from n = 55 individuals.

div.head: Statistical Analysis and Software
div.p: Allometry I used the power function 𝑦𝑦 = 𝛼𝛼𝑋𝑋 𝛽𝛽 where 𝑦𝑦 is the trait of interest, 𝑋𝑋 is pronotum width, α is the intercept and β is the slope (Huxley, 1924). I linearised this by log transformation to log 10 𝑦𝑦 = log 10 𝛽𝛽 + 𝛼𝛼 log 10 𝑋𝑋 which allowed the use of an ordinary least squares (OLS) linear regression to fit a line to the data, estimate the slope and intercept and perform a test to assess for deviation from isometry (𝛼𝛼 ≠ 1) using the smatr package (Warton et al., 2012;version 3.4-8). There has been debate regarding the appropriateness of different regression methods used in evolutionary biology, with OLS at risk of underestimating allometric slopes if there is measurement error in body size measurements. However, this bias is negligible when measurement error is low and OLS is still viewed as preferable in comparison with other methods (Kilmer & Rodríguez, 2017).
To account for this, all measurements were taken by a single researcher (NWB), and I thrice repeated measurements of traits on 20 individuals to ensure that measurement error was low.

div.head: Sexual Dimorphism
div.p: P. reticularis shows strong evidence of sexual dimorphism in selected traits with males having larger antennae than females, whilst females were larger in body length, body mass, pronotum width, elytron length, femur length, tibia length, wing length and wing area and wing loading (Full statistical details provided in Table 14). There was no significant difference in wing aspect ratio between males and females. The Kruskal-Wallis tests revealed no significant differences between male and female flight metrics (distance: χ2 (1) = 1.663, p = 0.197; duration: χ2 (1) = 1.419, p = 0.234; speed: χ2 (1) = 0.739, p = 0.390). Note: CV = coefficient of variation. Significant differences in mean trait sizes between sexes were assessed using Welch t tests. P-values were corrected for multiple comparisons using Benjamini-Hochberg method. *Both antennae were damaged in one female so was excluded from the antenna length analysis.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: In my investigation of sexual dimorphism in P. reticularis, I observed pronounced differences between male and female individuals across all measured traits, with the exception of wing aspect ratio. Female traits were consistently larger on average than males, with the exception of the antennae. Male antennae were significantly larger on average than female antennae which suggests sexual selection is acting on antennal length. Contrary to my initial hypothesis, an analysis of trait allometries did not reveal the positive allometry that is frequently used to infer the influence of sexual selection (Kodric-Brown et al., 2006;but see Bonduriansky, 2007).

Females showed negative allometry in antennal length, wing aspect ratio, and wing loading whilst all other traits exhibited isometry. In contrast, all male traits demonstrated negative allometry, except for wing loading which adhered to isometry. In the three areas of flight performance I explored, I discovered that wing loading was significant and positive, suggesting that as wing loading increases, so too does distance, duration and speed. As P. reticularis does not feed as an adult, the single objective of males is to mate with females which presents a fascinating study system to explore importance of different traits to success in a scramble competition mating system.

div.head: Sensory traits
div.p: The male-biased antennal sexual dimorphism apparent in P. reticularis is consistent with prionine antennae in general (Linsley, 1959), indicating the importance of detecting female chemical cues to the overall reproductive fitness of the male in this group (Barbour et al., 2006;Hanks & Millar, 2016;Paschen et al., 2012;Rodstein et al., 2009;J. D. Wickham et al., 2016). Increased antennal size/surface area has been associated with male fitness, improving the ability to detect weaker signals from females in Lepidoptera (Johnson et al., 2017). The observed elongation of male antennae in P. reticularis therefore may represent the optimising of mate-searching efficiency in this species.

Antennae are important sensory receptors, that are likely to be under different selective pressures. Directional selection is likely to have driven the increase in male antennal length compared to females. However, antennal length in both sexes of P. reticularis exhibited negative allometry suggesting that stabilising selection is occurring in both sexes, driving negative allometry. It appears that there is an interplay between directional and stabilising selection and I suggest that directional selection on the males is occurring within the constraints of stabilising selection as the allometric slope is very similar in both sexes (Male β = 0.769 & female β = 0.787).

The interplay of different selective pressures is likely very important in determining the maximum length or area of the antennae. As antennae provide information vital to male fitness they are likely to be under strong directional selection e.g., longer, pectinate antennae in males to detect chemosensory information on chemical cues involved in mate searching (Cardé, 2021;Johnson et al., 2017). This selection frequently leads to spectacular antennal morphologies which increase the fitness of the individual. However, there must be a trade-off; otherwise, I might expect the antennae to become even longer or with even greater surface area. This trade-off is likely to be one of aerodynamics, with drag increasing with antennal surface area resulting in greater energetic costs (Jaffar-Bandjee et al., 2020) and imparting a stabilising selective pressure leading to negative allometry. I conducted several laboratory experiments to determine the strength of olfactory response in males to female cues, however I was unsuccessful in eliciting mating behaviour in artificial conditions, indicating that unknown environmental factors may be important in this mating system. Future research would benefit from conducting field trials to explore and quantify behavioural responses.

div.head: Locomotory Traits
div.p: Morphological traits associated with dispersal (wing length and wing area) displayed negative allometry in males and isometry in females. Negative allometry in male wing traits is a pattern seen in several other beetle groups (Kawano, 1995(Kawano, , 1997;;Kelly, 2022). Kelly (2020) found that small body size and larger wing size in males, led to greater mating success in Popillia japonica.

However, this did not translate to positive allometry for wing area in this species, instead negative allometry was present with stabilising selection proposed to be at play on this trait (Kelly, 2022).

I found that flight performance (distance, duration and speed) increased with wing loading, but body size and wing aspect ratio did not influence flight performance. Increased wing loading is associated with higher wingbeat frequency, an increase in airspeed but a decrease in energetic efficiency suggesting the sustainability of flight is lower (Byrne et al., 1988;Dudley, 1999).

Different wing loading has been shown to be intimately related with defensive strategies in Neotropical butterflies, with species with high wing loadings relying on speed to escape predators, whilst species with low wing loadings fly in a slow and jaunty fashion relying on aposematism to avoid predation (Chai & Srygley, 1990). Therefore, the benefits to flight performance received from high wing loading values are likely to result in increased male fitness by maximising the number of females a male can get to. Whilst endurance (sustainability of flight) has been posited to be important and thus favour lower wing loading values, this likely depends on the spatial distribution of the female population (Husak & Fox, 2008). If females are located within a short distance of one another, then speed is likely to be a more important factor (Kelly, 2020).
Aspect ratio is important for agility and manoeuvrability. However, I did not see evidence of sexual dimorphism for this trait and it was not significant in the flight performance models.
Aspect ratio had the lowest coefficient of variation (CV) of all of the traits I measured (Table 14)

suggesting that this trait may be very constrained across body sizes. On the other hand, wing loading and body mass had the highest CV of traits measured, this suggests a great deal of variation within the sample population which is likely due to the differing ages of individuals. As the fat reserves of an individual are finite, the mass of the organism will decrease over time as these reserves are depleted whilst the wing area remains the same size. Wing loading will therefore decrease with age for each individual, resulting in more efficient flight over time but with a decrease in flight performance.

div.head: Body size
div.p: I found evidence for female-biased sexual size dimorphism (SSD) in P. reticularis, with males exhibiting significantly smaller and lighter body size compared to females. Small body size in males is thought to be beneficial in scramble competition, increasing their mobility and/or endurance (Andersson, 1994;Ghiselin, 1974;Herberstein et al., 2017;Kelly et al., 2008). One theoretical framework that may explain this is the Ghiselin-Reiss small-male hypothesis which suggests that in species exhibiting a scramble competition mating system, smaller males have a selective advantage in acquiring mates (Ghiselin, 1974;Reiss, 1989). The advantage is derived from a trade-off between allocating time and energy from feeding to mate searching. Smaller males, which require less energy per unit of time, can dedicate more time to energetically costly mate searching instead of seeking food, thus increasing the chance of encountering and mating with females.

In the context of female-biased SSD observed in P. reticularis, the Ghiselin-Reiss hypothesis provides a possible explanation. As the adults do not feed, instead surviving on larval energy reserves, a lower body size should increase the energy efficiency of flight. Flight efficiency is related to wing loading, a biomechanical variable relating wing surface area to body mass, with a lower wing loading value corresponding to increased flight efficiency, and a higher wing loading values associated with faster flight and higher body temperatures (indicating a greater loss of energy through heat) (Chai & Srygley, 1990;Dudley, 1999). Smaller, lighter males (in comparison to females) have a lower wing loading value decreasing the energy required for flight allowing for more efficient use of the finite energy supply thereby extending the length of time available to find spatially dispersed females.

Females are significantly heavier than males, and this was reflected in their larger wing loading value indicating a lower efficiency when flying. However, as mate searching is not required for the female, instead relying on a chemical cue to attract males, flying efficiency is less likely to be an issue other than when finding an oviposition site. This indicates that selection pressure is occurring on males but does not appear to be acting upon females and this drives the sexual dimorphism I saw.

div.head: Scramble competition and the selective pressures at play
div.p: Male success in scramble competition is governed by the rate at which they find and mate with females. Therefore, I predicted that as for male weapons and ornaments, positive allometry would be evident in sensory and locomotory traits. I did not find evidence of this, instead finding that all male traits of interest exhibited negative allometry. This suggests that the traits do not play a purely sexual function; traits with both sexual and non-sexual functions typically demonstrate isometry or negative allometry as observed here (Bonduriansky, 2007;Fromhage & Kokko, 2014).

In scramble competition, male fitness is linked to finding and mating with as many females as possible (Andersson, 1994;Ghiselin, 1974;Herberstein et al., 2017;Thornhill & Alcock, 1983) and has led to spectacular examples of sexual dimorphism such as the wingless, sedentary females in several species of bag moth relying on pheromones to attract males (Niitsu et al., 2017;Rhainds et al., 2008). In the case of P. reticularis, the female is fairly sedentary, attracting mates with a chemical cue and flying only when finding an oviposition site. This, combined with finite energy reserves, places selective pressure on male locomotory and mate searching traits.

One reason I might see negative allometry rather than positive allometry is that small males may be investing disproportionately in wing length and area as it provides an increase in marginal fitness gain for small males whilst larger males do not see a marginal fitness gain by investing further in wings, perhaps being constrained by a biomechanical or developmental constraint. A developmental constraint is a limitation or restriction that is imposed by the processes of development on the range of possible phenotypes that can evolve in a population (Frankino et al., 2005;Smith et al., 1985). However, determining the relative role of selection and developmental constraints is challenging without experimentally manipulating trait and assessing changes in fitness. Frankino et al. (2005) artificially altered the wing loading in a population of butterflies by selecting for differences in fore wing area. Over several generations this led to different allometries between the experimental group and the wild-type control. The wild-type were observed to have greater fitness, mating more frequently with females. This showed that the short-term evolution of new allometries was not limited by developmental constraints, instead natural selection appears to be exhibiting strong stabilising selection on male wing loading in this species.

In summary, my investigation provides evidence for selective pressures on traits associated with fitness in a scramble competition mating system. Most traits examined demonstrated femalebiased sexual dimorphism apart from antennal length which showed strong male-bias indicating the importance of detecting female chemical cues to male fitness. I did not find positive allometry indicative of sexual selection. Instead, negative allometry was prevalent in several traits, suggesting the influence of stabilizing selection. Wing loading was positively correlated with flight speed, distance, and duration. My findings provide insights into the trade-offs and constraints influencing the evolution of sexual dimorphism in P. reticularis, highlighting the need for future investigation, such as using artificial selection to tease apart and fully understand the dynamics at play.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: An animal's perception of its surroundings is vital for its survival and reproduction, and for insects the antennae fulfil a key role in reception of sensory cues to inform its behavioural decisions (Elgar et al., 2018). Antennae can be host to a variety of ultrastructures involved in mechanoreception, hygroreception, and thermoreception but are particularly associated with chemoreception (D. Schneider, 1964). Chemoreception relates to the detection of chemical cues in the environment (Zacharuk, 1980) and many insects are particularly influenced by such cues (Szyszka & Galizia, 2015), using them to locate host plants or prey (Geier et al., 1999;Paschen et al., 2012), make decisions about food quality (Haverkamp et al., 2016), choose appropriate habitats and oviposition sites (Paschen et al., 2012), avoid predators (Kannan et al., 2022) and locate and select mates (Johansson & Jones, 2007). Chemoreception can be further categorised into olfaction, analogous to smell, the perception of volatile molecules in the air, while gustation, analogous to taste, is the detection of non-volatile chemicals from surfaces (B. H. King & Gunathunga, 2023). Whilst the antennae are comprised of just three units; the basal scape and pedicel, and a flagellum, these can be readily modified as reflected in the incredible diversity in antennal morphologies across insect taxa (Elgar et al., 2018).

The basic sensory unit of the antennae is a sensillum, which is an innervated ultrastructure comprised of sensory nerve cells, trichogen and tormogen cells, and sometimes auxiliary cells (D. Schneider, 1964). Sensilla have been classified according to their structural morphology (e.g., peg and socket, hair, dome), wall thickness (e.g., thin walled, thick walled, single walled, double walled), presence and distribution of pores (e.g., terminal pore, wall pore, aporous, uniporous, multiporous, pitted, grooved) and innervation (e.g., number of sensory nerve cells, dendritic branching) (Altner & Prillinger, 1980). Whilst it is problematic to label the function of a sensilla based on its morphology without supporting electrophysiological evidence, there are sometimes clues which can help us to provide a tentative role to a sensillum type; for instance many chemosensory sensilla will usually have pores visible in the cuticle, through which odour molecules pass (Altner & Prillinger, 1980).

Darwin suggested that sexual selection, through female mate choice, could explain the seemingly bizarre array of traits that appear in some animal species, e.g., the "gorgeous plumage and strange antics" of male birds in attracting a mate (Darwin, 1859) that would seem conspicuous to predators and at odds with natural selection. Sensory traits that improve the ability of males to discover females were also postulated by Darwin to be under the influence of sexual selection (Darwin, 1871), but these have largely remained unstudied in the context of recent sexual selection research ( (Elgar et al., 2018). The reproductive benefit of finding a mate first can explain selection for longer antennae. For example, male Uraba lugens moths arriving at a trap containing a single female had, on average, longer antennae than males arriving at a trap containing two females, suggesting that longer antennae length improves the receptive ability of males to find a female pheromone plume at lower concentration (Johnson et al., 2017).

In species of insects that rely on female sex pheromones to attract mates, I frequently observe sexual dimorphism in the antennae. This may be obviously visible through an increase in antennal surface area through length of antennae and branching of the flagella, or, less visible to the human eye, through differences in the sensilla on the antenna (Elgar et al., 2018).

Morphology, density and distribution of sensilla have been shown to differ across a variety of insect orders. In the Mantodea, female sex pheromones are used by Pseudomantis albofimbriata as sensory cues in mate finding, whilst Ciulfina biseriata uses visual cues (Holwell et al., 2007).
Sensilla basiconica, associated with olfaction, are only present on the antennae of males of P.

albofimbriata. In contrast, C. biseriata, which used vision in mate searching, did not exhibit sensilla basiconica or dimorphism in the antennae (Holwell et al., 2007). Pheromones are well known in the Lepidoptera, and sexual dimorphism in antennal morphology is, unsurprisingly, common. Differences in the density and distribution of sensilla between sexes have been attributed to differences in importance of different sensory cues, e.g. female sex pheromones for males and host plant volatiles in females (Castrejón-Gómez et al., 1999;Hansson et al., 1995;Mark et al., 2018). Female produced sex pheromones appear to explain sexual dimorphism exhibited in Clitarchus hookeri (Phamatodea) with increased density of sensilla basiconica and sensilla trichodea, sensilla associated with olfaction, present in males (S. S. Myers et al., 2015). In some cases, the driver of sexual dimorphism of antennal ultrastructures can be less clear. This is the case with two species of closely related cave wētā (Orthoptera), Pachyrhamma waitomoensis and P. acanthocera. Several sensilla subtypes associated with chemoreception are absent in male P. waitomoensis that are not absent in male P. acanthocera, which may be due to differences in the structural complexity of the respective species' habitats (M. P. Fea et al., 2019).

Distinctive long antennae are a characteristic feature of cerambycid beetles, giving rise to their common name -long horn beetles (Allison et al., 2004). Typically, the antennae are filiform, however in some instances, these antennae may be strikingly modified, with comb-like flabellate flagellomeres, densely setose segments and, in one instance, a modified terminal flagellomere to form a venomous stinger (Berkov et al., 2008;Q. Wang et al., 2017). Sexual dimorphism is common in the cerambycids, and this is often most pronounced in the antennae with males having longer antennae than females. This suggests that there may be sexual differences in the sensilla present on the antennae which allow for the detection of chemical cues of differing importance to each sex.

Within the cerambycids, there are seven major types of sensilla present on the antenna (recently standardised in Haddad et al., 2023) which are: Böhm bristles, sensilla chaetica, chemosensory hairs (this term is used for any large, porous, hair-like sensilla i.e., sensilla trichodea and porous sensilla chaetica which have been used interchangeably in the literature), sensilla basiconica, dome shaped organs, sensilla coeloconica, and sensilla auricillica. Whilst only a few studies of sensilla in cerambycids have included electrophysiological data (Álvarez et al., 2015;Lopes et al., 2002;S. Wang et al., 2005;Wei et al., 2018), likely function of a sensilla can be supported by evidence from studies in other groups.

Böhm bristles are found on the antennal socket and between scape and pedicel in most insect orders and are mechanosensory in function (D. Schneider, 1964). These bristles are important in proprioreception, indicating the position of the antennae in relation to the body which has been shown to be important in positioning the antennae for flight (Krishnan et al., 2012). Sensilla chaetica are primarily mechanoreceptive in function (D. Schneider, 1964) with neurons of long and distal subtypes eliciting an action potential in response to movement whilst the stout subtype did not (Álvarez et al., 2015). Stout sensilla chaetica also do not show evidence of chemosensory functionality (MacKay et al., 2014;Sun et al., 2010).

Chemosensory hairs are divided into wall-pore hairs and terminal pore hairs which are proposed to have an olfactory and gustatory function respectively (Altner & Prillinger, 1980). Wall pore hairs, featuring multiporous walls and inflexible sockets, have been shown to have an olfactory function in Diptera (Clyne et al., 1997). Terminal pore hairs, featuring flexible sockets and a single apical pore, have been experimentally investigated in Lepidoptera and Blattodea with these structures showing both chemosensory and mechanosensory responses indicative of a contact chemoreceptive sensilla (Chun & Schoonhoven, 1973;Lambin, 1973).

Sensilla basiconica are small and cone shaped, with thin, multiporous walls and sit on raised bases (Haddad et al., 2023) with three sub-types: stout, thin, and grooved peg sensilla. Sensilla basiconica have been shown to play a role in olfaction with electrophysiology studies showing responses to host plant volatile compounds, sex pheromones and volatiles associated with burnt timber (Álvarez et al., 2015;Dyer & Seabrook, 1975;Wei et al., 2018).

The euonymous dome shaped organs are raised areas of the integument and are likely to have a thermosensory or hygrosensory function (Merivee et al., 2003(Merivee et al., , 2010)). Sensilla coeloconica, or "pit pegs", are small pegs that emerge from shallow depressions and are have a thermosensory or hygrosensory function if aporous (Waldow, 1970), and chemosensory if porous (Pophof, 1997).

Sensilla auricillica are cone like sensilla with a flattened depression, described as shoe-horn shaped. Electrophysiological studies have shown these sensilla to respond to host plant volatiles and sex pheromones in Lepidoptera (P. Anderson et al., 2000;Ansebo et al., 2005).

Prioninae are particularly noted for sexually exaggerated antennae and the flagellomeres of the antennae can be serrate, pectinate, imbricate or flabellate (Linsley, 1959). There is evidence to suggest that male and female prionines are both attracted to semiochemicals released by their host plant (Paschen et al., 2012), however only males respond to volatile female sex pheromones (Barbour et al., 2006;Edwards, 1961c;Paschen et al., 2012;Rodstein et al., 2009;J. D. Wickham et al., 2016). Mating systems with female produced sex pheromones, as found in the prionine beetles, tend to fit the category of scramble competition polygyny, whereby males try to mate with as many females as quickly as possible (Dickinson, 1992;Goldsmith et al., 1996;Goldsmith & Alcock, 1993).

The huhu beetle, Prionoplus reticularis (Cerambycidae: Prioninae), is the only member of the prionine family recorded in New Zealand (Sopow & Bain, 2017). The larvae feed on dead timber of native and exotic host plants (Edwards, 1959;Sopow & Bain, 2017) and are present across New Zealand. Adults are short-lived, non-feeding, large, and sexually dimorphic with males having longer antennae than females (Edwards, 1961c). A male-attracting olfactory signal is produced by female P. reticularis, and it has been noted that females attract males whether they are visible or covered (Edwards, 1961c). P. reticularis are also attracted to alpha-and beta-pinene lures suggesting that olfaction is important in the discovery of oviposition sites (Pawson et al., 2020). Stimulation of the antennae of either male or females elicits a defensive response, where the head is raised and lowered, the antennae flail and the jaws are opened and will seize on anything it comes into contact with (Edwards, 1961c). If this display occurs between two males, it can also lead to combat with the pair grappling one another with fore legs to flip one another whilst the mandibles seize any object that they come into contact with (Edwards, 1961c).

There are a paucity of studies in the literature of antennal ultrastructures in prionines with only males from two species, Titanus giganteus and Prionus imbricornis, being imaged using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) (Dvořáček et al., 2020;Haddad et al., 2023). Both studies found the sensilla in prionines to be markedly different to other cerambycid sub-families with an absence of sensilla chaetica and the presence of an unidentified sensilla resembling sensilla basiconica but unlike those found in other cerambycid groups. Dvořáček (2020) has suggested that sensilla chaetica are absent in Prioninae, however this requires further evidence.

In this study I use SEM to categorise the ultrastructures of both male and female P. reticularis to assess whether there is evidence of sexual dimorphism present in antennal sensilla and to expand knowledge of prionine antennal sensory architecture.

div.head: Methods Sample Preparation
div.p: Specimens of P. reticularis were collected using a light trap at Riverhead Forest, Auckland, New

Zealand in January 2021. The right-hand antennae were excised from four male and four female specimens. Using methods adapted from Haddad et al., (2023), the antennae were soaked in ethanol overnight, then rinsed in deionised water, and left to soak in dilute detergent overnight, before sonicating for 2 -3 seconds at 60 Hz. This was repeated a second time before a final rinse in 70% ethanol and then soaking overnight in 95% ethanol.
Antennae were mounted on stainless steel stubs with carbon adhesive tape then sputter coated with gold using a Leica EMACE200 (Leica Microsystems, Germany) for 60 seconds.

div.head: Scanning Electron Microscopy
div.p: Ultrastructural imaging was performed on a TESCAN CLARA field-emission gun scanning electron microscope (Tescan-Clara, Czech Republic) with the gun operated at 5 kV, a spot size of around 4 nm and a working distance between 11-and 12.5-mm. Images were taken of each segment of the antennae, from the scape to the ninth flagellomere.

div.head: Measurements
div.p: SEM Images were analysed in ImageJ v. 1.50i (C. A. Schneider et al., 2012). Following the methodology of Fea et al. (2019), I measured length of sensilla from the base to the apex, the width of base, width of tip and socket width for sensilla in both sexes (2 female individuals and 4 male individuals). The mean and standard error are reported.

div.head: Terminology
div.p: Ultrastructures were classified based on their morphology, insertion, surface features, porosity (porous or aporous) and location of pores (wall or terminal pore). For ease of comparison, I use the sensilla naming conventions outlined by previous authors, in particular the recent review of cerambycid antennal ultrastructures by Haddad et al. (2023) who standardised the sensilla of cerambycids into the following broad categories: Böhm bristles, sensilla chaetica, chemosensory hairs, sensilla basiconica, dome shaped organs, sensilla coeloconica, and sensilla auricillica. These categories were further subdivided into subcategories. Haddad et al. (2023) prioritised the terminology of Dyer and Seabrook (1975) who were first to publish on cerambycid antennal ultrastructure morphology, whilst also using the terminology of Altner and Prillinger (1980) to replace the inconsistent use of suspected chemosensory sensilla chaetica and sensilla trichodea found in the literature with the terminology "wall-pore hairs" and "terminal-pore hairs". I use the term sensilla filiformia from Faucheux (2011) to describe the long, ciliated sensilla which are prevalent in the male specimens examined.

div.head: Results
div.p: The whole antennae of the adult male and female P. reticularis are shown in Figure 34 A & B. The male and female antennae are both serrate and comprised of the scape, pedicel and nine flagellomeres. The surface of the antennae is covered in cuticular scales that are roughly hexagonal in shape with the exception of the base of the scape and the pedicel where it inserts into the head and scape. The scape is cylindrical, with a slight kink on the lateral surface. The pedicel is pocillovous in shape, constricted at the mid-point before widening at the distal end.
The flagellomeres are largely the same shape, with the distal end of flagellomeres one to eight protruding sharply on the distal, ventral edge, giving the serrated appearance of the antennae.

div.head: Böhm Bristles
div.p: Böhm bristles are present on the condyle, scape, and pedicel, particularly in the junction between these antennal sections (Figure 34 C & D). The conical Böhm bristles taper to a point and are set into a concave depression in the surface of the antennae. They are variable in length (Table 17)

and have no visible pores on the surface. Sensilla Chaetica (SC) Distal, Long and Stout Distal SC (Figure 35 B) were observed on the serrate protrusions of the antennae, set within a deep socket. There were between one and two present on flagellomeres 1 -8 and none observed on flagellomere 9. They are slightly striated, with blunt, pointed tips and aporous. Long sensilla chaetica (Figure 35 C) were rare and, if present, were found on the distal end of the scape and pedicel of both sexes. The surface of the long sensilla chaetica are aporous and striated with longitudinal grooves with the apex terminating in a sharp point. Of all the SC present, stout SC (Figure 35 A & D) were the most numerous on both male and females. They were present in greatest numbers on the scape and pedicel and the ninth flagellomere in females. They are shorter than other SC and variable in length. In most cases they emerge from a narrow depression in the cuticle and lie flat along the surface of the antennae, their sharp tips pointing distally. The surface of the stout SC is aporous and deeply striated with three corrugated openings present at the base (Figure 35 D). The stout SC in females appear to be more deeply striated than the SC in males.

div.head: Sensilla Basiconica
div.p: Stout & Thin Sensilla Basiconica Stout sensilla basiconica (Figure 37 A & C) were present on all flagellomeres in both sexes however were more prevalent on females than males. They are shorter than thin sensilla basiconica with a broader base and a blunt tip. The stout SB sits within a shallow socket on flagellomeres 1 -8 and a much deeper socket on flagellomere 9. I found possible evidence of pores on the surface of the sensilla. I also found one bifurcated example of a short sensilla basiconica which is suspected to be a developmental issue.

Thin SB (A, B & D) were rarer than stout sensilla basiconica but present on all flagellomeres in both sexes. They are longer and narrower than stout sensilla basiconica and have a sharper tip and variable in size. They were usually found amongst groups of stout sensilla basiconica, and more frequently on the distal flagellomeres particularly flagellomere 9.

div.head: Grooved Peg Sensilla
div.p: Grooved peg sensilla (Figure 38) are a sub-type of sensilla basiconica that were infrequently found on flagellomeres 1 -9 in both sexes but appeared to occur more in males. The sensilla are in broad, shallow, concave craters on the surface of the flagellomere. The wall and floor of the craters are wrinkled in texture. The base of the sensilla is broad, smooth, and circular in circumference, gradually tapering before narrowing distally to form deep, vertical grooves resembling digits.

div.head: Chemosensory Hairs
div.p: Terminal Pore Hair & Wall Pore Hair I found one candidate for a terminal pore hair (Figure 39 C & D) typically found on the edges of flagellomeres. They emerge from depressions in the cuticle and run parallel to the cuticle. The sensilla is robust in appearance with a broad base rising to a blunt tip. There appears to be a furrow at the tip of the sensilla which may imply a terminal pore.

I found one example of a possible wall pore hair sensilla (Figure 39 A & B) on the ninth flagellomere of a male. The sensilla is long, straight and hair like (but shorter than the surrounding sensilla filiformia) with smooth walls. The surface appears to have rows of pores suggesting an olfactory role.

div.head: Sensilla Auricillica
div.p: Sensilla auricillica (Figure 40) were irregularly present on flagellomeres 1 -9 for both male and female antennae. They emerge from a broad socket with the antennal cuticle forming a collar around the base. The general appearance is similar to those found by Zhang et al. (2015), a conical sensilla that has been longitudinally compressed with a concave depression from the base to the apex giving the appearance of an ear with the apex terminating in a papilla. There was some variation in shape and torsion, with some having broader, rounder bases than others. The surface is densely covered in pores, suggesting a chemosensory function.

div.head: Dome-shaped Organs and Sensilla Coeloconica
div.p: I did not find any evidence of dome-shaped organs or sensilla coeloconica present on the antennae of P. reticularis. that these are likely still sensilla basiconica with two subtypes identified -thin and broad. The sensilla in the sensory pits were typically surrounded by two to three corrugated, semi-circular glandular openings that are seen in other prionines, although the function of these is unknown (Dvořáček et al., 2020;Haddad et al., 2023). It has been suggested that sensilla chaetica may be absent in the Prioninae (Dvořáček et al., 2020) however I found examples of several sensilla chaetica subtypes on both male and female antennae.

Perhaps the most striking difference to other prionines is the dense pubescence of sensilla filiformia present on only the male antennae. This sexual dimorphism indicates that there is a role in reproductive behaviour, perhaps in mate searching or combat. Sensilla filiformia have been reported present in both sexes of the cerambycinine, Phoracantha recurva and are hypothesised to be mechanosensory receptors possibly related to wind detection (Faucheux, 2011). In this species, both sexes scramble to reach an ephemeral resource, stressed Eucalyptus spp., which may indicate that whatever the cue these sensilla receive is equally important to both sexes.

Electrophysiological data in Orthoptera supports a mechanoreceptive role for Sensilla filiformia, with detection of slight vibrations being of importance for predator avoidance (Gnatzy & Tautz, 1980;Steinmann & Casas, 2017). I can only speculate as to why sensilla filiformia are present in males. Whilst both males and females of P. reticularis are mobile, males likely spend more of their time in flight searching for females and could be perceived to need to process information relating to air movement (such as orientating to face the prevalent air current) or have an increased risk of encountering predators (such as Ninox novaeseelandiae, Edwards, 1961c). Other possible roles for mechanoreception in P. reticularis is in male-male combat and mate guarding.

These sensilla may provide information relevant to fights, such as opponent size. Males engaged in mate guarding post-copulation outstretched their antennae and attempted to orientate themselves towards individuals that make contact with the antennae (pers. obs.). These sensilla would be excellent candidates for electroantennography and transmission electron microscopy work in the future combined with behavioural experiments.

Sensilla are fundamental to how insects perceive their surroundings and understanding the sensilla present on antennae can allow us to make inferences into the life history of a species and its sensory ecology. Sexual dimorphism in the types, distribution, and morphology of antennal sensilla suggest that sexual selection is acting on the antennae, and in the case of P. reticularis, provides evidence for the importance of chemical cues for males in mate-searching. I also suggest that future research should explore the role of sensilla filiformia in males which may provide further insight into the mating system of P. reticularis.

div.head: Chapter 7 General Discussion
div.p: The study of insects as food is a multidisciplinary field, requiring research and researchers that can bring together different areas of knowledge to tackle the challenges that are found in this area. The aims of this thesis were twofold, to explore the social licence and cultural history of insects as food in Aotearoa New Zealand (Chapters 2 & 3), and to explore the biology of a wellknown edible insect, the huhu beetle Prionoplus reticularis (Chapters 4,5 & 6).

The success of an industry is contingent on its acceptability to the society in which it operates, and, in this thesis, I found Aotearoa to have a rich history of past insect use (Chapter 2) and a social licence for the nascent industry developing around edible insects. Survey participants' responses were nuanced showing that people were generally very open to eating insects and had a reasonable degree of knowledge and experience of edible insects in Aotearoa. However, this contrasted with insect ingredients being described more negatively than other more "conventional" ingredients (Chapter 3).

In Chapter 2, I collated a comprehensive catalogue of insects that have been used as food in traditional and more recent settings, which found considerably more edible insect species in Aotearoa than has previously been reported in the literature. Whilst there are several well-known native edible insect species documented, it was the off-hand references in the grey literature to lesser-known native insects used by Māori that hints at the knowledge that may have been lost or hidden following European settlement. Future efforts should be made to ensure mātauranga is not lost and this would benefit from kaupapa Māori led research. Recent work by O'Connor et al. ( 2023) is an excellent starting point for this, and demonstrated that there is (1) mātauranga regarding insect species and their uses that is not recorded in the literature and, (2) interest in greater access to traditional food types and the customs surrounding them. WAI262 will play an important role in shaping the edible insect sector and provides the opportunity to look at different ways of making insects accessible, for instance through the lens of food sovereignty.

We may benefit from the learnings of other countries' efforts to preserve traditional knowledge of edible insects. In Japan, a successful initiative connected older generations with school children to pass on their knowledge of insect use (Nonaka & Yanagihara, 2020). Chapter 2 also included a surprisingly large number of non-native insects used in contemporary ways, indicative of the diverse cultural make-up of Aotearoa and its connections to the rest of the world. One particularly fascinating and somewhat surreal highlight was discovering the export of wasp nests from Aotearoa to Japan in the 1990's. This no longer appears to occur, although at a recent conference I was approached by researchers from a Japanese university who indicated there is still a demand for this export. This raises the prospect of harvesting invasive species, which are plentiful in Aotearoa, for export overseas. This would dovetail nicely into government initiatives such as Predator Free 2050, although whether it is wise to encourage a sunset industry is debatable and may lead to an unwanted outcome to protect wasps to ensure livelihoods remain intact.

Chapter 2 also addresses a complicated legislative framework which makes it difficult for startups to produce food-grade products. I found a concerning trend indicating insect businesses struggle to be viable in Aotearoa. Over a ten-year period, out of the eight companies I found trading, only two appear to still be active, suggesting challenges to achieving commercial success in this market. Currently, the easiest route to market would be through wild harvesting of insects which carries risks of exploitation if not managed carefully. The viability of the industry is likely to be related to a variety of reasons, but one obvious area for improvement are regulations governing the production of insects for human consumption. Streamlining legislation, whilst maintaining food safety standards, would allow greater innovation in this space whilst providing consumer confidence in the safety of products. Whilst not explored in this thesis, by comparison Australia has a greater number of insects as food and feed companies and an industry body lobbying for the support of the industry. It would be prudent to learn from the successes of our neighbour, with which we already share some common legislature, as we develop our own industry. In the interim, start-ups could diversify their cashflow by producing insects for pet & livestock whilst they build capacity to sell to humans, allowing them access to a less regulated market reducing compliance costs whilst also honing mass production techniques necessary to make a product competitive.

Chapter 2 also found that companies selling edible insect products have relied heavily on sustainability and nutritional claims in their marketing, however there is little validation of these claims such as a life cycle analysis of their product, instead relying on research produced in other countries. It is well established (Halloran et al., 2016) that the sustainability of insects is very context dependent on the specific production techniques and species used and caution should be used when presenting generalised statements on the environmental benefits of insects. This is an area where researchers can play a role in supporting businesses, by investigating sustainability claims made in the context of Aotearoa. This will help increase consumer trust in the sector and potentially provide a competitive edge to products from this country compared to products imported from overseas.

The sustainability claims we saw in Chapter 2 appear to have permeated into the public discourse for insects as food. In Chapter 3, I found that words associated with cricket flour clearly matched the marketing techniques employed by companies e.g., as being environmentally friendly ("green", "environmental", and "alternative") and nutritious ("high protein", "gluten free"). Cricket flour was the insect-based ingredient with the highest positive sentiment score, ranking higher than conventional meat products. This presents tangential evidence that marketing of cricket flour has been quite successful and is a strategy that could be replicated with other insect products, such as "sky prawns". Huhu grubs and grasshoppers had a neutral sentiment rating similar to lamb, shrimp, beef and tofu and words associated with them related to their perceived flavours and textures, or to cultural references associated with these items. As the overall sentiment is neutral and they are largely associated with food, these species may have a low barrier to entry as a commercial food product.

There was a high degree of knowledge amongst participants, with 498 of 620 participants able to name one or more species of insect used as food, and 367 participants having eaten an insect in the past. I also found several attributes that predict the likelihood of eating insects in the future, with likelihood increasing with prior experience, existing knowledge, and a low food neophobia score. This suggests strategies to increase the acceptance of insects as food should focus on education, tasting experiences and incorporating into familiar dishes and by reducing the "insectness" of the product (e.g., a powder or flour).

In Chapter 2 I suggested that the easiest native insects to rear in NZ, these are Locusta migratoria and Teleogryllus commodus both of which are being farmed. P. reticularis could be another candidate albeit a challenging one due to it long lifecycle, but there have been strides in reducing to under one year in laboratory conditions, this, combined with the well-known status as a food in NZ society (Chapter 3), would make it the next most promising candidate.

A key finding in Chapter 3 was the tension between people's stated openness to eating insects and the predominantly negative sentiment of words used to describe most insect products. This may indicate an unconscious bias against some insect ingredients and could be indicative of a value-action gap amongst participants, i.e., expressing a willingness to eat insects, whilst this doesn't translate into the action of eating insects. This may also explain the limited success of businesses discovered in Chapter 2 and is an area that warrants further research attention.

In Chapter 2, I found several references to the flavour of P. reticularis varying based on the timber they are found in. This suggested that (1) biotic and abiotic factors influence the metabolic compounds within larvae, analogous to the influence of terroir on the metabolomic profile of wine and, (2) this quality might allow us to assess the provenance of an edible insect, i.e., fingerprint it to a particular location. Using GC-MS, I found that the metabolomic profile of P.

reticularis varied between locations and that a random forest classification model trained on this data was reasonably successful at determining the location of collection for a huhu grub. It would be worthwhile, however, to compare different models (e.g., SVM, SIMCA) to attempt to improve classification accuracy.

The ability to distinguish the provenance of an edible insect product provides several potential benefits. With the increase of trade agreements containing regional protections, it allows the detection of food fraud (e.g., a product being labelled as from a high value location but is actually from somewhere with a lower value). It also allows legislators or stakeholders to place restrictions, and detect infringement of those restrictions, on the sale of insects from certain locations, for instance due to concerns over sustainability.

However, it must be noted that I only explored spatial variation, and to validate this method I would need to further explore the effects of temporal variation and dietary variation on metabolites. There is already indirect evidence of diet influencing the metabolite profile of P.

reticularis (Chapter 2) and future research could compare the effects of different timber on the profile of the larvae. Given the mātauranga associated with the impact of timber on flavour, future research would benefit from collaboration with Māori to elucidate the physiological processes behind this. This research may also benefit insect farmers, given that the flavour of farmed insects is held to be inferior to wild-harvested insects (Evans et al., 2017, p. 179), a phenomenon likely driven by differences in diet.

The time of year will influence the metabolite profile as physiological processes such as cold tolerance and diapause entail changes to metabolism. I saw differences in two sugar compounds, mannose and trehalose, which are known to be important for freeze tolerance. They were the most abundant sugars identified in the larvae and varied along a latitudinal gradient, although in the opposite direction to what was expected. I have not been able to identify why this might be. I would expect these compounds to be more abundant in the cooler South and less abundant in the warmer North. It is likely that a controlled laboratory experiment would be required to tease apart what is happening here.

One element, I was unable to control for was the gut microbiome which is likely to interact with the metabolome and would be a fruitful area to investigate in the future. The gut microbiome is known to vary across the geographical locations of Costelytra zealandica and this is likely the case in P. reticularis (H. Zhang & Jackson, 2008). The gut microbiome of P. reticularis has been investigated in the past, but just from one location (Reid et al., 2011;Viswam et al., 2019). I found the five-carbon sugar, arabinose, to be weakly correlated with latitude, and in insects this sugar is utilised by gut bacteria which raises the possibility that the metabolomic profile is partially influenced by gut contents.

In Chapter 4, I also found proline and alanine to be the most abundant amino acids present, and these compounds are known to be important metabolites for powering flight in adult beetles. In Chapter 5, I investigated traits associated with flight and found that heavier males flew faster for longer. It would be interesting to investigate if proline and alanine abundance correlates disproportionately with increasing larval mass. Larger larvae, which in turn become larger adults, may have comparatively more of these amino acids than their smaller conspecifics providing better flight performance as an adult. If this is the case, then investigating the abiotic and biotic factors that govern larval size, could also assist in manipulating desired nutritional quality and weight. From previous work I have done on Hermetia illucens (Diptera: Stratiomyidae), black soldier fly, larval density and diet can greatly influence larval size (Birrell, 2018) and this is likely to also be the case in P. reticularis.

The majority of research on P. reticularis has been through the lens of its role as a forestry pest (Chapter 2). Other than the seminal work of Edwards (1956, 1959, 1961b, 1961c, 1961d, 1961a, 1965), little is known of many aspects of the life history of this species. However, understanding the behaviour of an insect species is crucial to successful rearing in a captive system. I sought to address this knowledge gap by investigating the mating system of P. reticularis (Chapter 5).

Chapter 5 highlighted how allometric patterns are a powerful tool for understanding the interplay of different selective pressures on an animal. The mating system of P. reticularis is characterised by scramble competition where males attempt to find and mate with as many females as possible. This puts selective pressure on male traits that improve their ability to acquire mates.

Locomotion and olfaction are critical for acquiring mates and this likely drives the sexual dimorphism I found, with males having longer antennae than females, and females being larger in all other respects. I hypothesised there would be positive allometry in male traits (e.g., antennae and wing size) with larger males investing disproportionately in these traits. This was not the case however, with most male traits exhibiting negative allometry. I attributed this to stabilising selection, with biomechanical constraints likely restricting excessive investment in traits.

In Chapter 5, I also designed and built six flight mills using a 3-D printer and low cost, everyday laboratory consumables and electronic components. This presents a novel way to collect data on flying species on a budget, or with limited access to laboratory space. I also developed a novel way of attaching beetles to the flight mill. Typically, low temperature hot glue is used, however this still appeared to cause discomfort to the beetle, potentially impacting their behaviour, and requires you to do this multiple times if the beetle needs to be reattached. To avoid this, I used a quick drying super glue to attach half of a staple to the pronotum of the beetle. This allows for the easy attachment of the beetle to a neodymium magnet which can then be removed and reattached as required.

In Chapter six, I further investigated the sexual dimorphism in antennae size observed in Chapter 5. Using scanning electron microscopy, I observed several sensilla that are only present on male antennae which have roles in chemoreception and mechanoreception in other taxa. This again emphasises the importance of detecting females using sensory cues for males of this species. The sexual dimorphism was particularly striking in the dense sensilla filiformia present only on the male antennae. These have not been reported on any other prionine beetle (Haddad et al., 2023) and in other insect orders have been attributed to mechanoreception (Faucheux, 2011). In hawk moths, the speed of flight and pectinate antennal morphology are optimised to slow the passage of air and ensure the capture of odour molecules (Jaffar-Bandjee et al., 2020). I hypothesis that the dense sensilla filiformia on the male antennae of P. reticularis perform a similar role, acting as a mechanoreceptor to provide dynamic information on flight whilst also slowing air flow over the antennal surface to ensure pheromone molecules are captured by chemosensory sensilla.

I attempted a variety of different experiments to quantify mating success, strength of olfactory responses and captive breeding in this species, however these were unsuccessful due to a variety of reasons such as the beetles not exhibiting normal behaviour in a confined environment, the relatively short breeding window in which adults are active, and a pandemic and lockdowns corresponding with field seasons. Whilst disappointing at the time, these challenges did drive innovation (particularly in the construction of the flight mills) and highlighted some of the challenges of trying to rear P. reticularis in a closed system for the production of insect protein.

With the benefit of more field seasons, I suspect it would be possible to overcome these issues and eventually devise a rearing protocol. However, if commercialisation was the goal, a simpler solution might be to pursue semi-domestication similar to the production of palm weevils in the tropics. In this scenario, a solution might be to prepare an attractive ovipositioning medium, perhaps with kairomones attractive to female P. reticularis, such as α-& β-pinene lures developed for monitoring forestry pests (Brockerhoff et al., 2006). Following this, it might be possible to allow females in the wild to inoculate this media. If so, this would be a straightforward way to proceed and could be done in tandem with further research into captive breeding.

div.head: Concluding remarks
div.p: In summary, there are challenges faced by the edible insect sector but, with proper support from academia and government, there is great potential for growing the industry further in Aotearoa.

Culturally, there is an acceptance and existing awareness that insects can be food and this may reduce the barrier to uptake that is seen in other Western nations. The rich cultural history, and diverse array of edible insect species available, offers an opportunity to showcase edible insect species whilst preserving and celebrating traditional food practices. A sustainable source of domestically produced protein could provide increased food security and sovereignty to communities in Aotearoa, whilst diversifying our agricultural sector. Reaching high densities in our pine plantations, the huhu grub is perfectly placed to champion this movement. I hope this thesis can act as a foundation for future work to build upon whilst also adding to our understanding of a charismatic native insect, Prionoplus reticularis.

industry is based on, at least, partnership with Māori if not Māori leadership. Of particular consideration for the commercialisation of any endemic insects in New Zealand is the WAI 262 report, Ko Aotearoa Tēnei(Waitangi Tribunal, 2011). WAI 262 was lodged by six iwi claimants to the Waitangi Tribunal, a standing commission of inquiry relating to alleged breaches of Te Tiriti o Waitangi by the Crown, in 1991. Often called the flora and fauna claim due to its particular focus on kaitiaki relationships with flora and fauna, it also encompasses kaitiaki relationships with the environment, protection, and transmission of mātauranga Māori, taonga works and, intellectual property (IP) relating to taonga species. As the first whole-of-government claim, its complexity is reflected in the extensive timeline with the hearings completed in 2007 and the report being issued in 2011, twenty years after the initial claim.

answered "Prefer not to say". I split the data set (n = 560) into training (n = 419) and test (n = 141) sets with the test set only used to assess the final model. Both the training and test sets were stratified by gender to minimise sampling bias arising from the imbalance between male and female. From the training data set, I used bootstrap resampling to create 25 new training and testing sets with which to evaluate the models. As the outcome variable was imbalanced (I had 3.25x as many likely to unlikely), I used the synthetic minority over-sampling technique (SMOTE) (Chawla et al., 2002) to create synthetic data for the minority outcome class (unlikely) in the training dataset, allowing us to train the model efficiently without altering the testing dataset and reducing the risk of overfitting. I compared a logistic regression, random forest, and a Bayesian logistic regression model and selected the model using the confusion matrix, the area under the receiving operating characteristic (ROC) curve (AUC), specificity, and sensitivity. A confusion matrix contrasts false positives and negatives with true positives and negatives predicted by the models. Specificity measures how well the model correctly classifies actual positives a percentage, whilst sensitivity is a percentage of how well the model correctly classifies actual negatives. A ROC graph plots the true positive rate on the Y-axis and the false positive rate (1 -specificity) on the X-axis. I found the logistic regression model to perform best on the training data and used this as the final model.

Due to an imbalance in sample size between males and females, I performed a Levene's test which revealed the groups being compared did not have approximately equal variance for distance and duration (p = 0.006, p = 0.01 respectively) but was approximately equal for speed (p = 0.639). Due to this, I performed a non-parametric Kruskal-Wallis test.To assess how wing dimensions affect flight performance in males, I used three generalised linear models (GLM) with a gamma distribution with a log-link function to predict (1) average flight duration in seconds, (2) average distance in millimetres, (3) average flight speed in metres per second, using body size (pronotum width in millimetres), wing aspect ratio and wing loading as predictors. div.head: Ethics
div.p: Ethics approval was received from the University of Auckland Human Participants Ethics Committee on 10 March 2020 for three years (ref: 024336).

div.head: Results
div.p: There were 620 total responses to the questionnaire. Most respondents were Female (n = 422), European (n = 474), from Auckland (n = 267), in the 25 -34 age bracket (n = 222), with a postgraduate university education (n = 264), an individual income of between $50,001 -$70,000 (n = 121) and had an omnivorous diet (n= 473). In response to the question "have you eaten insects before?", 367 (59.2%) participants responded 'Yes'. The demographic breakdown of participants is presented in Table 4. The sample is not representative of the New Zealand population for the characteristics of gender, ethnicity, age and education and so generalisations for the whole of New Zealand should not be made when interpreting the results.
Specific Beliefs/Attitudes Towards Insects (Figure 3)
The participants' specific beliefs and attitudes relating to the consumption of insects is shown in Figure 3 with disgust, risk, benefits, ethics and naturalness measured using nine items.

Participants were grouped by those who have eaten an insect before ("Yes" group) and those who have not eaten an insect before ("No" group). Disgust was measured with the statement "eating insects is disgusting". The yes group tended to disagree (66%) with this statement more than the no group (31%). Participants' perceptions of risks associated with eating insects was measured with three statements "eating insects will increase risk of infectious disease", "insects contain harmful toxins" and, "insects carry harmful microbes". Both groups showed similar patterns in response to these statements with a majority of participants selecting neither agree or disagree in response to the toxins and microbes statements. In the statement which specifically mentions the consumption of insects ("eating insects will increase risk of infectious disease"), the majority of participants disagreed with this statement (71% & 63%). Statements investigating benefits of eating insects ("insects are highly nutritious" and "eating insects is good for the environment") received majority agreement from both groups (92% vs. 75%; 77% vs. 58%), however there was a greater degree of uncertainty found in the "No" group (7% vs. 20%; 20% vs. 31%). Ethics statements included "insects are capable of feeling pain" and "killing insects is immoral", the majority of both groups agreed that insects feel pain (52% vs. 56%) but disagreed that killing insects is immoral (67% vs. 55%). Finally, for the statement "it is not natural for humans to eat insects" the majority of participants in both groups disagreed (84% vs. 70%) although there was a difference between groups in those who agreed with the statement (5% vs. 15%).

div.p: Chapter 4 The metabolomic fingerprint of an edible insect species, Prionoplus reticularis (Coleoptera: Cerambycidae), along a latitudinal gradient.

div.head: Abstract
div.p: Molecular fingerprinting of food items can provide information on the species, geographic location and quality of an organism making it a useful tool for identifying food fraud, provenance and assessing quality. Metabolomics is frequently used for this purpose due to its ability to identify and quantify metabolites at a high resolution. This study investigates the efficacy of untargeted GC-MS metabolic profiling using two different derivatisation techniques, MCF and TMS, to fingerprint an edible insect species -the huhu grub (Prionoplus reticularis)along a latitudinal gradient. Huhu grubs, the larvae of Aotearoa New Zealand's largest longhorn beetle, are a culturally significant and commonly eaten insect throughout its range. I found that the accuracy of a random forest model trained on the TMS-derived metabolite profile was superior compared to MCF. I found several compounds, including arabinose and urea, that had a weak, linear correlation with latitude. Compounds with high relative abundance in this species were mannose and trehalose, which are known to be important for freeze tolerance in other species, and exhibited a surprising trend along the latitudinal gradient which warrants further research. Proline and alanine were the most abundant amino acids present, and these compounds are known to be important metabolites for flight in adult beetles. I suggest that future research should investigate the metabolomic signatures of temporal and dietary variations in this species, which would further validate the use of metabolomic fingerprinting in this species.

div.head: Allometry
div.p: Full allometric statistical outputs are provided in Table 2 and Figure 4. In summary, the wing length and area and tibia length of P. reticularis exhibited negative allometry for males and isometry for females. Antennal length of P. reticularis exhibited negative allometry for both males and females. Ninth flagellomere length exhibited isometry in both males and females. Wing aspect ratio exhibited very low correlation with pronotum width (wing aspect ratio male, r2 = 0.063, female, r2 = 0.071). Wing loading exhibited isometry for males and negative allometry for females. Note: F9 = ninth flagellomere. Wing area has been reduced to one dimension by square root prior to log transformation.

div.p: The model's explanatory power is substantial (Nagelkerke's R 2 = 0.32). The model's intercept, corresponding to corresponding to body size = 0, wing aspect ratio = 0 and wing loading = 0, is at -1.19 (95% CI [-3.78 is large longhorn beetles exhibiting a scramble competition polygyny mating system with sexual dimorphism present in antennal length, suggesting chemical cues are of importance in male mate searching. I investigated antennal ultrastructure morphology and sexual dimorphism in this species using scanning electron microscopy. I identified several sensilla that were only present in males: sensilla filiformia, sensilla auricillica, wall pore hairs and distal sensilla chaetica. These sensilla are known to have chemosensory and mechanosensory functions in other insect groups, suggesting these senses play an important role in male mating strategies.

Above this protrusion is a small, sharp spur, mirrored on both the lateral and medial faces. The ventral surface of the antennae is densely pitted, with each pit containing several sensilla. The dorsal, medial surface has fewer pits, usually containing a sensillum. The terminus of the ninth flagellomere is rounded and laterally compressed with well-defined pits. The male flagellomeres are densely covered in sensilla filiformia with flagellomeres 6 -9 at least as long if not longer than flagellomeres 1 -5. The female flagellomeres do not have the sensilla filiformia found in the males, however they are densely pitted and flagellomeres 6 -9 are reduced, being smaller than flagellomeres 1 -5. Average (arithmetic mean) measurements for individual sensilla length are presented in Table 17.

div.head: Sensilla filiformia
div.p: The flagellomeres on the male antennae are densely covered in long, aporous, ciliated sensilla filiformia that are not present on the female antennae (Figure 36 A). I was only able to distinguish one type of sensilla filiformia present, characterised by their wavy, ciliated and flexible appearance, frequently entwining around one another (Figure 36 D). These structures give a slight pubescent appearance to the male antennae that is visible to the naked eye. Longitudinal striations run from the base of these sensilla up to around one third of the length of the structure. Several sensilla filiformia were broken at the base or apex which revealed a hollow structure through its length (Figure 36 C). The sensilla are situated in shallow insertions and surrounded by two to three corrugated openings (Figure 36 B).

div.head: Sensilla on the Ninth Flagellomere
div.p: On the ninth flagellomere of males, I found several different sensilla types that emerge from inside deep pits surrounded by cuticular collars (Figure 41). Two of the sensilla appear to be similar to sensilla basiconica but inset into the cuticle. I tentatively label these as sensilla basiconica broad (Figure 41 B) and thin (Figure 41 C & D) however further examination using transmission electron microscopy is required.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: I described the sensilla ultrastructures present on the antennae of male and female P. reticularis providing the first ultrastructure investigation of an endemic prionine and first investigation of a prionine in the Meroscelisini tribe. The most abundant antennal sensilla present on the antennae of both sexes, sensilla basiconica, are associated with chemoreception further supporting the importance olfaction plays in this species perception of its environment (Edwards 1961;Pawson et al., 2020).

I found evidence of sexual dimorphism in the antennal sensilla, with several sensilla types only found on the male antennae. The most abundant ultrastructure, present only in males, were sensilla filiformia suggesting that these sensilla are important in male behaviour. Also present only in males, but in low numbers, were sensilla auricillica, wall pore hairs and distal sensilla chaetica. Grooved peg sensilla were common on male antennae but rarely seem on females.

Sensilla auricillica showed a multiporous surface and are proposed to be involved in the reception of female produced sex pheromones. The sensilla chaetica of the female antennae featured much deeper, more pronounced striae than male sensilla chaetica. Whilst the functional significance is unknown, the sensilla chaetica may be related to the female assessing physical characteristics of suitable oviposition sites, as I have observed female P. reticularis using their antennae (and ovipositors) to interact with substrates prior to laying eggs.
There are only two studies investigating the antennal ultrastructures of the Prioninae, both

showing highly unusual antennal ultrastructures when compared to other cerambycid subfamilies. The antennae of both sexes of P. reticularis were covered in the sensory pits reported in the other two prionines studied (Dvořáček et al., 2020;Haddad et al., 2023) and contained a sensillum similar in structure to the sensilla described variously as coeloconica (Dvořáček et al., 2020) and unidentified prionine sensilla (Haddad et al., 2023). I agree that there are differences to the sensilla basiconica found in other cerambycid subfamilies (Haddad et al., 2023) but suggest
